I am a retired physician with some weird heart rhythms and wanted to be able to check my status between checkups.  It is very frustrating to experience feelings of my heart skipping beats, yet by the time I get to my doctor’s office for my next visit, my rhythm is stone cold normal.  This device allows me to capture pictures of my heart rhythm when it is acting up.  Then, if it is necessary, my doctor can order a 12 lead EKG, or a 24 hour Holter monitor to fully assess my rhythm.  It is invaluable when such rhythms are sporadic, since you can capture the irregular rhythm and relate it to time of day, activity, stress, caffeine, etc…. This device does not replace a 12 lead EKG, or a 24 hour monitor, but it does an excellent job of identifying the 4 basic concepts of heart rhythm interpretation.  Fast; Slow; Regular; Irregular.  It also does a fairly accurate job of allowing measurement of QT intervals, QRS width and, in many cases, the differentiation between PVCs and PACs.  You need to have a physician’s opinion for true identification of these issues, as well as things like heart blocks and brief periods of A-fib, but to get you started and to monitor yourself between doctor visits, this device is very much worth its purchase.  I use it for home monitoring for my family.  I am quite pleased with this device and am glad I purchased it.

My dad has A Fib and he was having issues with RVR, rapid ventricular response. We were looking online for something that could up us identify if his rhythm changed and when he needed to contact his doctor or go to the emergency department. We purchased the  AliveCor Kardia device and loved it!  One night we were hosting family game night and we were so excited about our new technology toy that we thought it would be fun to do tracings on everyone there!! It was all in fun and amazement at the new cool technology gadget!! However things became serious when my cousins husband who was completely asymptomatic and had never had heart issues had his tracing done. It was not what we were expecting. We discovered his heart rate was 144 and the device suggested "Possible A Fib". We were very concerned and repeated the tracing several times with the same results. This device is not a doctor but it can tell you when to call your doctor or go to the Emergency Department. So my cousins husband did not take it lightly and had further testing done which revealed he had 4 cardiac arteries blocked. His widow maker was 100% blocked!! He underwent quadruple bypass surgery and has recovered nicely. He was completely asymptomatic and we truly believe that this device saved his life. Thanks AliveCor!! We are firm believers in your device and so glad that it is available to the public.

I am extremely glad to have an Alivecor to check my heart rhythm to determine whether or not I am in Afib.  I appreciate the capability to email the readings to myself at a different email and print the readings to share with my doctor.  He does not do email.   I like being able to record the activity before the reading or how I feel.  I am now enrolled in a cardiac study at Johns Hopkins Hospital.  They are giving the volunteers an Alivecor to take readings and able to be monitored by the study staff.  I figure Johns Hopkins has confidence in Alivecor.  Three cons with Alivecor.  First, I wish the phone case was a bit stronger to protect the phone.  Second, there should be more detail in the analysis.  There are three choices, Normal, Unclassified and Possible Atrial Fibrillation.  I understand Normal and Possible Atrial Fibrillation.  I don't understand Unclassified.  There may be some limits imposed by the FDA.  However, I would like to know some of the parameters that might fall under Unclassified.  I have figured out that Unclassified may include bradycardia beats under 49 bpm and tachycardia, beats over 100 bpm.  Not sure if I am correct.  What is included in Unclassified between those numbers?  Third, the response to emails for diagnosis do not contain enough detail.  Responses seem like canned messages.  These are minor.  The device provides confidence knowing I am in rhythm. details for my doctor when not in rhythm.

My wife and I live in Rio Vista, Ca. Her cardiologist advised us to buy the AliveCor device because of her SVT attacks. Several months later, in October 6, 2016, she had what she thought was a bad SVT attack. We used the AliveCor with the Kardia app and it indicated she was in AFib. She was hospitalized two days because of its severity, but no heart attack. Cut to Nov 9, 2016, around 8:40 in Palm Springs. I'm using my smartphone, when I experience burning indigestion discomfort. Take anti acid, but it worsens. Feel pulse in carotid and it's erratic. Use the AliveCor and it registered unclassified, three times in 5 minutes. I know what my normal ECG looks like and knew I was in trouble. I called 911, EMT arrives 5 minutes later, does their thing and 10-15 minutes,  I'm in the hospital heart attack. Within another 25 minutes or less, I'm have an angioplasty procedure to remove a 90 percent blockage to the Left Anterior Descending. Little to no heart damage. I can't say enough about the AliveCor. It has already saved my wife's life and mine. 
Recommended Improvement:
Currently the device reads Normal, AFib or Unclassifief. I'd like to see a Possible STEMI, or Possible Heart Attack reading. 
I talked up AliveCor before this happened, but now I'm telling everyone in their 60s to consider purchasing it. One other thing. The medical staff in Palm Springs was amazed when I showed them my readings and easily identified PVs and the STEMI.

I am a Physician Assistant who works in a 30+ bed/24 hour a day urgent care.  In the past 3 years I have seen many patients in "A fib".  Many had know idea anything was wrong.  Some came in for anxiety, palpitations, and some for chest pain.  Those who knew were "paroxysmal" patients suspecting recurrence.

As for me, I figured a Pneumonia, and boy was I wrong!!!  Out of the gate I had afib RVR, or "Rapid Ventricular Response". In lamens terms, your heart's bottom half is accelerated or accelerates with minimal exertion.  This can lead to V-Tach, venticular (the bottom half) tachicardia, which if left un-treated is a "lethal rhythm" as it is known.  Even simpler terms "not good" :-)

For me, I now back in "Normal Sinus Rythm" thanks to an electrical cardioversion.  This is where a surgeon or ED doc drugs you up (if you are lucky) and shocks your hear out of A fib (again, if you are lucky you heart complies).  

I now have a history of A fib, and if it happens again to me I will have "paroxysmal" A fib.  God forbid it does not convert one day, then Chronic Atrial Fibrillation.

My low risk at 46 years old and otherwise healthy means I won't take blood thinners most likely.  This means I need to know if I go back into A fib quickly so I can go get shocked right away. The Kardia is going to let me do that by my taking my tracings every couple of days or with suspicion.  

It is now the most powerful tool in my very recently changed life and I am 5-star grateful to have it!!!

Like the "Wizard of Oz" scene, AliveCor is hoping reviewers focus on the smoke and mirrors of its device and not what's behind the curtain. The device works well enough, and if that's all you base a review on, "wow it's a 5!"

But even more important than taking a recording is reporting those recordings to your doctor, and this is where AliveCor falls on its face.  The reporting capability both online and on your phone a woefully pitiful. Your doctor will laugh at you while cursing AliveCor.

Log onto their website, and the first thing you notice is that the online reporting offers no way to search individual reports - you literally have to scroll through potentially hundreds of readings to find a particular tracing. Your doctor will love that!

Worse, the website inaccurately aggregates reports.  In one test where half the reports were SR-SVE and the other half SR, it failed to list any of the SR-SVE!  Only by scrolling through hundreds of potential tracings can you identify individual results.  Imagine your doctor fiddling around on a website trying to find which recordings to examine?  AliveCor is clearly more focused on the flash of its device than the usefulness of its website to physicians.

I can go on, but you should be getting the point. Most reviewers who have given AliveCor a favorable rating have only focused on the flash of its device.  No one seems to pay attention to what happens when you want your doctor to review those recordings.  

...And that's where AliveCor falls flat on its face.

Most noticeable is that the AliveCor device contact pads are easily dented and scratched indicating that metal used is dead soft and not of a harder grade metal or plated with a hard coating to make the device more resilient being so exposed.on the back side of a cell phone.  The plastic holder for the AliveCor has two small "flex bending spring ears" at the lead-in of the holder if th we AliveCor device is removed from the holder....those spring ears protrude slightly and because they are rounded off and are of a slightly higher profile first one got snagged and broke off then the second one saw the same fate. Now I must watch that I don't lose the AliveCor device altogether. It has already slipped out of the holder and dropped waist high to a hard surface causing me to hope the AliveCor device has some "g" shock survivability built into it.  Regarding the output...the waveform displayed shows almost too much sensitivity to the point my Cardiologist has said "so much background static in the waveform produced that it bordered on almost being useless".  The Dr is the one who recommended AliveCor and now considers it "a toy" and not medical grade enough for him to the point that a Medtronic LINQ Loop recording device was implanted within me at his recommendation. The AliveCor device also responded that a possible AF was recorded when my Cardio Dr. quickly and easily identified the recording as having many PAC's in it indicating with the Dr. now saying that the algorithm programmed within the AliveCor was not able to distinguish between a series of waveforms that were indicative of AF from that of a series of much less harmful PAC's in the recorded series of waveforms. So too many false positive AF feedback.  I have owned and used my AliveCor device since Sept. 4, 2015.

We live in a very stressful world and life isn't getting easier. 

I've been to the ER more than once because of episodes of tachycardia, shortness of breath, elevated BP, a sense of imminent doom: those of us past middle-age and many younger people know the routine. Each time I was there, an EKG was part and parcel of the standard tests they ran to rule out a heart attack. 

Now, I never had a heart attack that they could find or even a mini-stroke. But I worry a lot and that's just the way I am. When I heard about Alive Cor's device, I was curious but held off because it was being promoted as a tool to help those afflicted with diagnosed AFIB. And my physicians have never found AFIB. So, it seemed logically contradictory and also a waste of $99 to buy one. But I did. 

And I this is only the second day of owning it, but I feel better. Aside from having a family history of stroke and sleep apnea, worrying about the possible scenarios and consequences just made me feel bad, even though nothing was really wrong.

What the KardiaMobile provides me with is the assurance that I can check if I feel a little "off" to see if I have a normal EKG or not. I can have a history of my normal EKG's on file to compare with any future ones and while the device isn't for self-diagnosis, it can help me to decide whether or not I need to seek further medical assistance. The best part is that the test is quick and you can take as many "snapshots" as you want. Alive Cor has changed their policy so that you can save your tests for yourself at no additional cost. The only fault I found seemed to be based in the newest version of Android software. I was unable to record any voice notations. All I got was a loud hiss and jumbled words. So I turned that "feature" off until they fix it. 

But be assured, being able to rule out AFIB, which can affect anyone or to just be able to check for a "normal" EKG goes along way in helping affected people or worriers like me feel better. Well worth the small investment.

AFIB AND TRICKINESS TO GET READINGS. Afib is a heart condition, that I watched my mother struggle with.  Unfortunately she was unaware of what was happening as her mental condition was deteriorating.  Afib is also sporadic and  unless a doctor sets you up on a holter monitor for the span of time it is happening, you never get proof. With an event monitor, you need to know the Afib is happening.  I also found, a typical home style blood pressure cuff cannot accurately detect the erratic heart rate that Afib presents.  You get a error.  Manually you can measure it, but unless you are a nurse  you may not know how to do this accurately. I am not a nurse.  ALIVECOR APP IMPRESSED MY DOCTORS: The Alivecor app and device is literally a life saving option.  If you think you have Afib, you just whip out the sensor (I dont have mine attached to my phone) and start your app and you get a reading.  I had suspected I had Afib, but my primary physician was thinking it was all in my head.  I knew better having researched my Moms condition.  I purchased this monitor and showed my doctor the readings I was getting and finally I was referred to a heart doctor. She was amazed at the technology and felt it was compelling.  This is essential.  Afib can cause strokes and if you get it under control and on a blood thinner you may well avoid any complications.    My heart doctor was enthusiastic to see the readings.  He loved that not only did you get the info, but you also got the trace.  I even managed to get a trace where I converted from Afib back into sinus rhythm. That was useful as there is sometimes issues with this.  I am now being treated for this condition and have scads of data besides the extra tests the doctor put me through.  I feel I can manage my condition as an individual.   SETUP AND USAGE: I downloaded the app and put it in record mode and the first trace was sent to validate the unit and I was ready to go.  I found you cant use it, when it is plugged in and also if you move too much it will mess up the trace.  Occasionally it takes a moment to start a reading, but I have found finger position matters and a few times I had to restart my phone.  Thank you Alivecor.

Microsoft 3600 Bluetooth BlueTrack Mobile Mouse (PN7-00002) - Black
comment:
Read the instructions!  I'm staying at a hotel and discarded everything but the mouse and battery before I went inside.  The mouse worked at first but stopped working when I rebooted, and wouldn't work in my 2nd installation of Windows 10 on the same laptop, nor on Windows 10 on my ARM-based Samsung.  After 15 minutes of scratching my head, I finally realized that you need to press and HOLD (not simply turn on) the Bluetooth button for the computer to see, pair with, and connect with the mouse.  Then it comes up instantly as Bluetooth Mobile Mouse 3600 and stays connected after rebooting.

One minor complaint is that you can't easily switch the mouse between two running instances of Windows on separate laptops.  What happens is that the mouse will connect to one and remain paired on the other.  There is no way to reconnect without clicking "Remove device" and holding the button again.  After all of these years, Bluetooth still feels like a half-baked technology, at least in Windows.  You would think Microsoft would put a "Reconnect to paired device" in the Bluetooth settings.

I wish the mouse came in exciting colors like cinnabar red or Persian green or zaffre blue.  Black is so boring.

For me, when rebooting, there is a brief, almost unnoticeable loss of connectivity immediately after logging into Windows when the Bluetooth icon first appears in the system tray.

I bought this particular mouse for 3 reasons:

(1) My favorite mouse in terms of comfort and precision is Microsoft Mobile Mouse 4000 so I wanted to try another Microsoft product.  I find most Logitech mice too complex and unwieldy at the high end, and too flimsy and plasticky at the low end, and haven't found my personal Goldilocks with their mice.  

(2) The back of the box says this mouse is compatible with Windows 10, macOS from 10.10.3 onward, and Android from 4.4.2 onward.  No mention of iOS or iPad but 3 out of 4 is pretty impressive.

(3) My much-despised ThinkPad T480 company laptop only has two USB 2.0 ports and a tiny (for me at least) M.2 SSD.  I'm often working with massive files and folders as a cell site tech.  Up until I bought the Bluetooth Mobile Mouse 3600, every time I needed to transfer data from one external USB hard drive to another (because there's not enough room on the internal SSD), I had to disconnect my Microsoft Mobile Mouse 4000 and use the dreaded, glitchy trackpad or (gasp) the red nubby snazzlefrazzum and I would sometimes inadvertently move dozens of folders to the wrong locations or delete entire folder trees in an unintended fatfinger calypso dance.  The bluetooth mouse solved this problem for me brilliantly.

comment:
[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] As a user of the earlier-generation OM4 smartphone gimbal, I am incredibly impressed with the OM6.  It's a worthy upgrade (even if you don't really have the need to extend the "selfie-stick").  Slimmer and lighter with better controls than the previous generation OM4, the OM6 feels good in the hand and works intuitively once you get the hang of the custom controls.

Within a few minutes of having the gimbal out of the box, I had it working with the app on my iPhone 13 Pro Max (yes it fits in the clamp and the gimbal motors are more than a match for my phone and it's case).  I'm glad they did away with the adhesive mount and only include the clamp.  The clamp holds on tight and is easy to attach and remove without sticking around to ruin your wireless charging plans.  This is another big improvement over the OM4.  I had the OM6 smoothly following our cat around the living room.

There are so many shot options in the app, but the ability to select and follow a subject and the ability to sit the gimbal on its included tripod (or another full-sized tripod with the threaded mount) and take time-lapse video are my favorites.

Stabilization is as smooth as you'd want, even with a big phone and battery life is everything I need - I never ran out of juice in my testing.  The USB-C charging is also very fast, so even if you do manage to run it dry, you won't be waiting long.

If you're in the market for a gimbal for your phone, it's hard to find any reason not to recommend the OM6.  I use a larger DJI RSC2 for my mirrorless camera, but with mobile camera video quality and portability, I prefer to reach for my phone and the OM6 when I can.

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment:
[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] The design of the DJI Osmo 6 is thoughtful. The body feels to be made of a plastic which I imagine would be good for shock absorption but may lead to some durability issues if not treated with care. It folds which is great for portability. While the device could probably fit in a pocket, l think that it fits better in a small bag, purse, or backpack. The controls are well placed and feel very comfortable for one-handed use.  The joystick feels precise. The extendable selfie stick is really useful—especially when trying to get a group shot.

The magnetic phone holder is another really nice touch. It allows for quick placement and removal on the phone, which is great for situations where you would need to do that like reviewing footage between takes. I didn’t try any of the accessories but they look like they would be nice upgrades.

The gimbal itself is powerful and makes a huge difference in shot stabilization. If you are shooting in conditions with a lot of movement this is going to offer a serious improvement. Using the joystick to pan is super smooth as well.

There are a ton of great features included with this product; the most valuable (to me) being the ActiveTrack 5.0. Simply put, the device in conjunction with the app is able to “lock on” to the video’s subject while filming. It works amazing and gives a very specific effect to the content which is heavily featured on Tiktok, Instagram, and other social media platforms. 

The DJI Mimo app is amazing. It works as intended and adds a lot of functionality to the device. I tested it with my iPhone but it works with Android as well. 

Overall this is a great device. I would recommend it to anyone looking for a gimbal with great tracking and a number of features.

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment: [This review was collected as part of a promotion.] I’ve been considering getting a system like this for awhile.  Particularly for vacations when I want to do videos and those selfies with the wife in nice locations where you don’t necessarily want to go looking for someone to take photos for you.  Overall, the Osmo is easy to setup.  No complications that I recall.  The phone holder looks unassuming and almost too light for the task.  So far though, it’s held my iPhone 13 Pro Max, in case, without issue.  Don’t know that I would try this setup hanging from a vehicle or anywhere where the motion of the carrier would be excessive.  Using the controls is easy but does take some getting used to.  More because this is my first time with a device like this so remember what button to multi-click, to do what, is taking some time.  With more use I’m sure it’ll be muscle memory though.  The tracking feature is nice, but could use some work.  It seems to track me fine if I move from side to side in the shot.  If I standup from a desk position though, it does not tilt enough to keep my face in view.  Not a deal breaker, just something to be mindful of and plan accordingly for.  It’s great they include the tripod, instead of making it an accessory that has to be purchased separately.  It would be awesome if they could find a way to incorporate a tripod in the handle though, so you don’t have to worry about keeping track of that extra item.  I haven’t used it enough to speak to battery life.  The extension is good, but for me it could probably use one more section.  The extension should help get some nice low angle shots.  It is a little bulky.  I think the marketing stuff showing this in folks front pockets is a bit laughable.  It is a good size for a backpack or camera bag though.

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment:
[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] The DJI Osmo 6 is an amazing phone gimbal.  I have been using an Osmo 2 for the last few years but the Osmo 6 is a serious upgrade to my previous model.  

Setup takes less than a few minutes, you download the DJI Mimo and pair it with your smartphone and you’re off and ready to go.  A nice new feature of the osmo 6 is that when you unfold it it automatically turns on.  If you need to start recording quickly that is a great feature.  The holder for the phone is magnetic and will stretch wide enough so that you can leave your phone in a case, which my previous osmo could not do.  The osmo will also automatically open up the Mimo app upon connection!  The stabilizer for the phone is much more fluid and stronger than previous models.  Sometimes with my osmo 2 if I didn’t have the phone balanced in the right spot it would kind of flop over and be non functional.  I didn’t experience that at all with the new osmo 6, even with the added weight of a case.  The active track 5.0 is phenomenal and allows you to stay focused on a face or object.  The osmo will keep it in focus the entire time no matter which way you turn it.  They’ve also added the ability to extend the osmo with a retractable arm that will allow you to get more people in the frame or get lower to the ground effortlessly.  The osmo also has 4 shooting modes: Follow, which follows the gimbals pan and tilt movements.  Tilt locked, which only uses the gimbals pan movements.  FPV mode, which utilizes all 3 axes of the gimbal which is the mode I use the most for Real Estate video walkthroughs.  Spinshot utilities the joystick to rotate the camera to make dynamic footage.  Finally there’s a new side wheel which allows you to zoom in and out effortlessly while recordings. All of these features combine for a very good phone gimbal.  I highly recommend the osmo for anyone who needs an inexpensive gimbal to stabilize photos or video.  It really is one of the best products that DJI makes in my opinion.

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment:
[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] This is a rather impressive piece of hardware.  The folding/unfolding mechanism, magnets to attach the phone and stretch phone mount make it easy to attach your phone and get up and running quickly.  The gimbals and motors really do keep the phone steady/the video stable and it can track people which is a nice touch.  The joystick also moves the phone just where you want it smoothly without jerking and the buttons give you rapid control to start/stop recording, flip the phone from portrait to landscape and other key features.  It also feels good in the hand with a good heft and solid feel without being too heavy which is huge.

Where it lets down a bit (for Android users at least) is on the software side.  Due to a dispute with Google (and, to some degree, the US government), DJI's app is not available on the Google Play store, and must be downloaded and "sideloaded" from their website.  This means that you must enable installing non-Play Store apps in the security settings of your phone, turning off one of the security features of Android (with that setting turned off, it will let you install - purposefully or not - apps from ANY source).  It's also a setting that some corporate environments require you to keep enabled.  So, for Android users at least, this is an issue.  

Once you get the software installed, either on Android or iOS (where it is found in the Apple App Store), it's a pretty nice experience, giving you quick tutorials on the major features and letting you use some of the buttons to control the phone directly (it guides you through pairing the phone and the gimbal).  Overall, the software is a big plus for the device - BUT I do wish it was directly available in Google's Play Store (DJI, can you work on that!)

All told, this is a really nice package (with the one caveat about Android users) for those looking to get better video, but still looking to use their smartphones/not invest in an expensive dedicated camera.  You can shoot cinematic looking videos easily and be the envy of all your followers - which is the goal, right?

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment:
[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] While initially slightly disappointed in the included 'instruction manual', it was made up for by following the QR code and going where I needed.  That'll be an .apk download you'll have to give your phone permission for, but the app is super helpful.  Well that and it's very nearly mandatory for complete, proper use of the gimbal.
Because of that, I feel that the app is integral to using this device and needs to be brought up in the review.
The device itself is sturdy and has a good weight to it.  Most of the controls will be in easy reach of most users, with only the zoom/focus wheel posing any kind of problem for those with shorter thumbs.  Along those lines, it does seem to be designed heavily toward right-handed use, and that may just be a statistical design choice.  The magnet on the phone clamp feels strong and left no worries that the phone would drop from the gimbal, and the arm is strong enough to hold likely any phone currently on the market.  Controls are simple to use and grasp once you know what they mean, and that's where the app really shines.
As stated, the app is pretty much mandatory for proper use, as it connects via bluetooth to join your phone and the gimbal.  Without it, most of the buttons don't properly function, if they do anything at all.  The app, aside from granting full use of the device, grants full use of all camera controls by using the camera through the app.  It also contains a number of templates and such to help make quick movies, with direction on how to set them up and pull the shots you need.  Speaking of direction, you should find your way to the tutorial videos included within the app, as they give a step by step breakdown on how to use the device, what each of the settings mean and are capable of, and how to make the most out of your new accessory.
Aside from the instruction manual issue, my only gripe is that I have to remove my case every time I want to put my phone in the gimbal, as I couldn't get it to function well with the case on--it seems to throw off the motors and the magnet.

Overall, 4.75/5.

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment:
[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] DJI have some of the best drones on the planet. What happens when they take that gimbal technology and introduce it to cell phones? You get smooth video footage in a compact package without breaking the bank in the Osmo Mobile 6.
I was expecting a much larger piece of equipment. However, this thing is relatively small.  When closed and in the storage position, it is about an inch longer than an iPhone 12 ProMax. It includes tripod feet that screw into the bottom for hands free self-recording. The mount is a standard ¼-20 screw mount that is found on all current photography tripod so you can even use one of those to hold the gimbal and phone for recording. The phone clamp is quite strong an holds the iPhone 12 ProMax with ease to the gimbal with a very strong magnet that will not allow the phone to drop. Also included in the box is a USB cord to charge the internal battery and a suede pouch to keep everything together.
The first thing that caught my attention is the quick on feature built into the device. Once you unlock the lock that keeps it from flopping around in an off state and flip up the arm the device turns itself on. This save seconds that could be used to capture the action sooner.
The Osmo mobile 6 has four modes for how the gimbal operates. They are Follow, Tilt Lock, FPV and Spin Shot. For most Vlogging scenarios Follow mode is the most used. 
The DJI Mimo app that is paired with the Osmo has several tutorials that will get you familiar with the use and functions. Also, there are tutorials for shooting specific scenes.
Some the newer features of this model that differ from the previous version and a smooth operating side wheel for zoom or focus. With a press of the side wheel, you can select either the zoom or the focus function. Another nice, upgraded feature is the joystick control that allows for smooth panning. The third feature is a screen that shows which mode the gimbal is set to.
Overall if you are looking for a device to get smoother video footage out of your phones camera this thing is great. If you already have a capable smart phone and want to get into vlogging or just shooting more video with your phone that can look more professional, this is probably what you are looking for. 
All in all another great product from DJI.

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment:
[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] This is my first smartphone gimbal, so I was super excited to get this Osmo 6 version and try it out.  After a little bit of a learning curve, I love this thing!

Right out of the box, you’ll notice that hard copy instructions or quick start guide material is lacking.  For iOS users at least, that’s not a problem because you simply scan the included QR code and the app store takes you right to the DJi app to download, and the app immediately recognizes the Osmo 6 as the item you’re using, and begins walking you step by step through all the initial setup process, and explaining all the features along the way, in both text and videos.  The app tutorial is quite impressive.

It uses a super strong magnet base attachment for your phone, that easily expands to fit large phones with cases.  I’m using an iPhone 14 Pro Max with an Otterbox case, and it has no trouble fitting inside the expanding base attachment.  This then secures to the Osmo 6 with a strong magnet, allowing you to securely shoot your videos and photos, and remove your phone in a snap at any moment.  The magnet is strong enough that I have no worries at all about the phone coming off the mount.

Controls are perfectly placed no matter which hand you use to shoot with. You have controls for tilting and panning, quick access to front or rear cameras, zoom and manual focus control, preset modes for different shooting styles and a trigger for activating follow mode, to stay locked on to your subject as you or they move around.  Also the buttons have double click features that allow extended options like flipping from portrait to landscape mode in a breeze, or re-centering the gimbal.  It also has a tripod stand for table top placement and a built in extension rod.

It uses it’s own DJi app for the video and photo controls, which I haven’t had a problem with.  You get more controls over the aspects of your shots compared to Apple’s built in camera app, and you have the ability to customize things like ISO, Shutter Speed, Resolution and FPS, etc.  The controls are pretty intuitive and easy to use, and the 3 axis stabilization really shows in your final videos.  Everything is super smooth and centered, so much better than just using a traditional phone holder or selfie stick.  The learning curve for me was adjusting to the “non” movement of the camera angles that I’m accustomed too, based on body and hand movements while filming.  Letting the gimbal offer precise balance and stabilization is wonderful, it just takes a little getting used to in order to perfect your shooting style with it.  So much fun to play with.

It has a sold build, and pretty lightweight, not overly heavy, and folds down to a respectable size for travel.

I don’t know that I ever want to shoot mobile video without a gimbal again, and the Osmo Mobile 6 has been the perfect tool for me so far.

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment:
[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] If you’re looking to up your photography or videography using your mobile device, this stabilizer will help you accomplish that! Working the best with the DJI MIMO App and an iPhone, you’ll find you get some amazing features with this gimbal stabilizer. You get 3-axis stabilization, a built-in extension rod, and ActiveTrak 5.0 allowing you to track even the most difficult subjects and keep them in frame. 

Unboxing you’ll find the main Osmo Mobile 6, the magnetic phone clamp, the tripod, charging cable, and a little storage pouch. Getting the Osmo Mobile 6 setup is very simple. Download the DJI MIMO App and it will pair via Bluetooth to your phone and walk you through tutorials on how to operate the different features and modes of the device. While you can utilize the gimbal without connecting to the DJI MIMO App, you do lose some functions like ActiveTrak, switching between cameras, switching shooting modes (photo/video), using the focus or zoom wheel, or using the record button. The functions of the gimbal continue to work, but obviously any feature that relies on communication to your phone becomes very limited. 

Overall, the DJI Osmo Mobile 6 has a ton of features to allow flexibility and get you professional looking stabilized footage. With ActiveTrak, not only can you make sure your subject stays perfectly centered in frame, you can also use the included stand and have the gimbal follow you around even if you’re shooting something by yourself. This is a huge advantage if you’re a content creator on the go and use your phone a lot to shoot footage. The built-in tripod mount is also a huge advantage allowing the ultimate flexibility for whatever mount you need to connect the Osmo to. On top of all of those features, the gimbal will also extend into a selfie-stick. 

The different gimbal modes give you a good amount of flexibility on which axis you want to lock down or prioritize. You have Follow mode which will lock your orientation angle but allow you to pan up, down, left, and right. The second mode is Tilk Lock, which will only follow your left or right panning. If you need to pan up or down, you will use the joystick on the Osmo. The 3rd mode is FPV mode which will unlock all 3 axes. Not only will you get panning, the camera will now be allowed to change it’s orientation angle. The final mode is SpinShot allowing you to control the orientation angle using the joy stick. For me, I found the 1st mode the most natural, while modes 2 and 3 allowed some flexibility depending on what shot I was attempting to achieve. 

In conclusion, if you’re needing a compact, feature rich gimbal stabilizer, you don’t need to look further. DJI is a leader in image stabilization from their gimbals to their drones. They make great products and back them with good customer service. I’ve seen some users report issues or limited functionality using Android devices, but I’m confident DJI will be able to fix those bugs moving forward. For the best experience, pairing with an iPhone and the DJI MIMO App will not leave you disappointed.

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment:
[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] As a first time user of a gimbal I was very impressed upon opening the box to find the DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Stabilizer has a high quality look and feel. Inside the box you'll find a brief instruction booklet tucked inside a suede holding pouch, the gimbal, a phone clip magnetic stabilizer unit, a mount grip attachable tripod and a charging cable. You must provide your own charger and I simply used my Apple iPad model which worked perfectly.

I then downloaded the DJI MIMO app and was pleased to see it offers a Beginner's Guide plus Tutorials which are really helpful for a gimbal newbie such as myself. There was a firmware update V01.00.02.40 that went in after I connected my iPhone 12 Pro Max via Bluetooth (which worked flawlessly) and placed in the phone clip stabilizer unit, then attached it to the gimbal. 

There are various function buttons on the gimbal, a battery indicator and also a built in extension rod for taking those low shots or views from above your subject or just because the scene calls for it. This rod pulls out from right above the settings area. The app is set to come on automatically when I attach the phone, a super nice feature. When you want to turn the gimbal off simply remove the phone, flip it down into a folding position and it's off. It's small enough to easily carry and the pouch will keep it safe.

Another great feature is the Active Track 5.0. I have a 2 year old granddaughter and was so excited to have her over to try this out! Oh my gosh the stabilization went perfectly and the video of her and my daughter is a real keepsake! With the Osmo 6 you have none of the jerky, annoying quirks you get if just holding the phone in your hands, especially action shots. Believe me my granddaughter gave me plenty of running around for action! The videos I took look very professional too!

We also rent out a B&B property on 15 acres of land and I can't wait to use this for filming out there when we reopen in spring. A virtual tour should look amazing online, especially with all the nature scenery around. This gimbal is perfect for any real estate or scenery usage in my opinion.

I also did straight PHOTO shooting for my online antiques, collectibles and jewelry store. I love how you can zoom in on jewelry marks by using the side wheel (left side). Press once and it controls focus or turn the wheel so it zooms in and out on your object. I found it so much easier to spend time photographing my various items using the Osmo gimbal than doing it freehand with my digital camera. The gimbal is pretty lightweight therefore my arm did not get tired nor did I have to twist and turn my body to get that perfect shot like when using the camera. There is also the tripod which was attached and for some of the shots that was the way to go. Everything turned out wonderful!

There is a joystick to control the direction and an M button to switch between portrait and landscape modes and also to use the front or back cameras. Other features are available but I suggest you definitely watch videos on YouTube about the DJI Stabilizer for tips, tricks and usage. There are a number out there and all seem very informative. Of course you have the built in app videos which are extremely helpful, especially if you are new to gimbals.

This is an item I wasn't sure about liking, even though I photograph tons of things. But after using it the last few days I must say now it's indispensable! When I go in to shoot pics it's the first thing I grab in my photography room. From class act videos to photos, the DJI Mobile 6 Stabilizer does it all, works beautifully and is a delight to use! I highly recommend it!

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment:
[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] This is essentially a gimbal for your cell phone camera. Sure, I've used my cell phones and action cameras over the years for pictures and video, and I've done quite a bit of work using tripods and lighting rigs, but this is the first mechanical stabilizer I've used.  This is way more than just a selfie stick, it has all kinds of capabilities to fundamentally change the way you capture video and images. It was a pretty steep learning curve for me to get used to how it works and how to use its functionality, but I feel like I started thinking like a movie cameraman.  It's just a wildly different experience to have this device control the actual positioning and tracking of the camera and video.
The app is full of guides and tutorials, so there's lots and lots of learning material right there available to you. It even can offer suggestions for how you create certain effects and how you use its features.  So yeah for me it was scary to take on this whole new skillset but the app can guide you every step of the way.  I'm still learning and getting the hang of how its features can enhance the content that I create.
Otherwise this little machine is extremely well built, the motors really do their job positioning that phone in three axes, and it's pretty quiet and the battery lasts a good long time

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment: [This review was collected as part of a promotion.] As a stabilizer, this thing rocks.  Videos come out very stable and the stabilizer does a good job accounting for your movements.  It folds down very small and comes with a magnetic phone gripper and legs and storage bag.  If you are lucky to have a phone that you can put the phone grip on in the middle of the phone and have a perfectly balanced phone in the stabilizer, you will have no problems.  If you are unfortunate to have a phone where if you put the phone grip in the middle of the phone in a balanced position, you might have the phone grip constantly putting pressure on the volume button or power button.  Luckily, the gripper opens up big enough that it can be placed over my Google Pixel 7 Pro in a Spigen Tough Armor case and avoids pressing the volume down button.  Instructions are very lacking in the box and will take time to fumble around to figure out how to use it.  The DJI app is not in the Google Play store thanks to embargos, so you have to manually download and install it yourself.  Once you have the app installed and paired with the stabilizer, the app walks you through the entire feature set. Overall, if you can get your phone onto this stabilizer without any buttons being pushed, you will be very happy with the performance of this stabilizer.  Of all the knockoff stabilizers I have tried, DJI really did an amazing job and is well worth the price if you need stable videos.

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment:
[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] I can't say enough wonderful things about the DJI Osmo Mobile 6 stabilizer. All that is required is to download the app onto your phone and you're ready to start creating videos. 

Let's discuss the features. The first feature of course is the stabilizing feature. It does a great job at keeping the camera steady as I even had my daughter hold the camera and check out how well it stabilized. Okay, that's just one little feature. Another great feature is with the app open, you can set the stabilizer up to actively track someone or something. I first tried the feature on a cat (The cat wasn't amused), then I tried the feature on myself just walking around the house, and the stabilizer tracked perfectly (It was a little slow but very smooth). The app itself has so many different features that I can't even list them all, as I'm continuously learning about them as I use the stabilizer. Another great thing about the stabilizer and the app is that as you access new features it gives you simple step-by-step tutorials to follow, which makes learning how to use the stabilizer a breeze. 

Overall, I'm super impressed with it, from the active track to the features on the app itself. This is a great product!

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment:
[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] I am not a professional photographer, but I am a bit of a photography enthusiast.  I mostly focused on still images mainly because handheld video is never easy to get right.  

So this is the first gimbal I have ever used and I must say I am very impressed.  Video while moving is super steady and the ability to track targets is incredibly useful.  Still coming up with different ways to use this feature as it opens up so many possibilities.

In the box you get the gimbal, phone clip and tripod and charging cable

Out of the box, set up is easy and intuitive - scan a QR code and download an app, pair the gimbal with Bluetooth.  The app offers lots of training for newbies like myself via tutorial videos.  And you pick up a lot just by experimenting with the different features.  

Physical controls are in easy to use places, and the wheel for zoom and button for swapping between stills and video are very useful.  The gimbal is well balanced and ergonomically designed.

This is an easy device to recommend to anyone wanting to take their cell phone videos to the next level.

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment: [This review was collected as part of a promotion.] Yes. I'm an Android enthusiast. My Samsung S22 Ultra is a great phone, but I understand Apple gets a lot of the third party compatibility. Maybe that's due to the fragmentation of Android. Who knows? But I really don't appreciate companies that claim to be compatible with Android who are not truly compatible. This DJI Osmo Mobile 6 is a perfect example of that. Apple has an official app you can find in their app store, but Android is left with an APK (that my anti-virus program warned me about downloading) that needs to be side loaded. There needs to be more effort in labeling this on the box and in the product description. However, it still works for stabilizing, just don't think you'll be able to take advantage of all the zoom features and controlling options the stabilizer has. Luckily, I am mainly using it for family memories, so my Scorsese skills in film making will not need a lot of these controls. But I'd love for it to be available if the product is priced the same no matter if it all works or not. It'd be nice to have an Android edition, that may lack all features, but would be cheaper. The build quality is excellent though. Not too heavy, but hefty enough to feel the quality materials used. All in all, I'm glad I own it because as a stabilizer it works well. I just wish it was truly compatible with Android officially.

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment:
This is a solid and portable gimble, from its hardware to its mobile app! It has a slight learning curve but is very easy to grasp. 

You will have a wide range of stable and directional control for your videos/photos, and the extender arm and the tripod attachment make it a bonus for hitting those angles or those POV and selfie shots. 

I am also impressed with the thumb access to all of those buttons to trigger all of your iPhone's video and photo features without using the touchscreen. It is a very efficient and well-thought-out user experience. It would also be great if the trigger finger button could be customized as the video record or photo snapshot button.

My only gripe is the MagSafe clamp for iPhones using a protective case, as it could interfere with your buttons and continuously trigger them. It takes a little finesse, and it depends on your protective case, but you might be able to avoid it. Centering the MagSafe clamp is not difficult once you have done it a few times.

In some cases, you might need to offset the positioning of the clamp to avoid button triggering, which could also affect the gimble's auto-balancing feature in landscape mode. The gimble may also use more battery life to maintain its balance during landscape mode.

However, if you still have button/balancing issues with the DJI MagSafe clamp, I came across a perfect adapter mount if you Google "DJI magnetic ring holder phone clamp mount." It works perfectly with Magsafe iPhone cases and with the DJI Osmo 6 gimble!

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment: [This review was collected as part of a promotion.] The DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Stabilizer is one of the coolest products I’ve used in some time. Right out of the set up is super easy, scan the QR code to take you to the app store and download the DJI Mimo App and pair it via Bluetooth. Once in the app there are multiple tutorial videos that help you get familiar with the DJI Osmo Mobile 6, which is a nice feature to have so you're not having to Google or go on Youtube to learn how to properly use this device.  The metal mounting clip is one of the better mounts I have come across, in that it stretches wide enough to grasp around my Iphone 14 Pro Max with a case on, I was for sure thinking that my case was going to be too bulky for it but it was able to. The Mimo software is great in that it basically mimics my iPhone’s camera interface but with some more options on the screen depending on which setting you are in, such as in photo mode where there is a shutter timer where you can pick from 3 seconds, 5 seconds and 7 seconds. In the Video mode it allows you to pick the resolution (720P,1080P or 4K) and what frame rate you would like to shoot in, which is super nice being able to pick that right from the camera interface and not having to dive into the setting to find it. Then the most outstanding feature of the DJI Osmo Mobile 6 has to be the head tracking feature in that when shooting video, a green box shows up and the arm will literally move and follow your head as you move which is perfect for filming things such as content or family videos. The buttons on the DJI Osmo Mobile 6 are very intuitive in that you get a Zoom knob, a record button, a focus stick that allows you to move the arm like you would with the right stick on a game controller, and A landscape to vertical button. There is a trigger button on the back of the handle that is not as intuitive and I highly recommend watching all the tutorial videos to learn all of its little tricks. In summary I think this is one of the best filming accessories you can buy to truly get the best photos and videos on your cell phone.

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment: Bought this item almost 2 months ago for real estate film making with my iPhone. I had had the OM5 and to be honest, not much of a difference, at least for what I need it. If you have the OM5 model and you don't think the zoom button is something useful for you, than no need for upgrades. Otherwise, if you don't have phone stabilizer, definitely buy! Very noob friendly and useful for great content!

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment:
[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] As a mobile platform gimble, this phone option is amazing.  From the various options provided within the initial presets to aide in learning how to setup, use, and take the best images and videos.  Mobile photo and videos have taken over normal photography options with what’s being made avail today.  Find my normal camera spends more time in it’s carrying bag these days when want that quick shot, my mobile is my go to.  It does take a little bit to set this up for first use with a firmware update during the initial setup.  Once past this and going through the various training videos provided within the app, some calibration to support the phone better (Samsung and Pixel Pro), thigs got only better.  This is very responsive in hold to movement for vertical and horizontal filming.  For first timer’s, this may seem a little overwhelming going through the initial steps depending on how familiar you are with what you’re presented.  For those with experience and/or knowledge, should walk through fairly easily from adding the app to your mobile device, establishing the Bluetooth connection, and getting to the operational play state.  Setup and play time took appox. 30 minutes due avid background with DJI product, other gimbals, and photography/video.  Part the time included playing around with all of the options presented to annoying some of my family while out and about taking footage of high-rise buildings.  Someone special had their own paparazzi for a little bit.

The gimble itself looks and feels very sturdy, easily unlocked and opened for attachment of your mobile device.  The magnet system on this and phone clamp attaches to the phone securely.  Perhaps one of the most notable changes added are the zoom and focus options as they aide you in getting your best shots.  It does telescope out to aide in those 360 degree and weird position footages where you need the extra length to capture appropriately.  I would highly recommend this for any new or current photographer looking for something to use with their mobile device.

To note, had to add one of my own wrist straps and capture cord to hand form my neck in the event I should drop the unit as nothing like this was provided in the box; a foul perhaps with the cost tied to this.

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment:
[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] I enjoy creating digital content videos, photos, and reels in my spare time and was fortunate to find the new DJI Osmo Mobile 6 stabilizer. I was using an android and an iPhone to create the content which was fun to shoot on vacations and occasionally use a selfie stick with a remote control. I was so happy when I found the new DJI Osmo 6 Stabilizer which immediately made me realize why the price was set above what I expected for my first experience with the brand. I started with the unboxing of the product and noticed immediately that the luxurious quality of the device was far greater than I ever expected. I saw the various sturdy buttons along with the digital display that provides the status of the device and the type of recording you are set to start. Even the tripod stand was a higher quality of plastic and sturdier than my prior product. 
 I was impressed with how strong the magnet was to firmly hold my brand-new iPhone 14 Pro Max which is not a light phone. When I hit the commands to flip my phone from portrait to landscape mode, I was thrilled to see it so quick and effortlessly. I downloaded the DJI application for my smartphones which I saw in the instructions and on the box. I found the setup videos and multiple device instruction videos to be extremely helpful for a newbie to the brand.
I was able to pair it immediately via Bluetooth with my iPhone and it immediately started the setup process on the DJI Osmo gimble and in the application on my phone. I was like a kid having fun when I tried the various activities they take you through from shooting videos, to choosing a smaller area to target for video and then moved into the photo mode. After completing each task, it would flash a congratulatory type of message to let you know you were doing everything correctly. I was relieved that with so many features available on the device that the simple instructions took away the anxiety of having to learn how to make another accessory compatible with the smartphone I was using. I was able to use the device a couple of days before writing this review, so I found the best aspects of the smooth operating system that was satisfying for taking a chance on this new brand. I have already produced new media content and loved that the video stabilization feature proved to be great at keeping the final video from looking too shaky. I am confident that the Osmo Mobile 6 Stabilizer will be my go-to accessory when I create my special projects and for even fun family events to get everyone in the picture or produce even better videos 
I would highly recommend this product to my friends and family who have smartphones that are compatible with the devices listed on the company’s app and website. I look forward to many adventures with the brand and using their products on my international trips along with content created at home regularly.

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment:
[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] Take your videos and even pictures to the next level.  This thing is awesome!  In the box you will find the device, stand, carrying case, and magnet for your phone.  I used this with an iPhone 4 pro and setup was a breeze.  During the app setup there is a quick tutorial that will help you understand how each button functions.  There are many short cuts like pushing certain buttons twice to change from wide or portrait mode.  It will take some time to learn the short cuts and become acclimated with it.  The website also offers guides and tutorials as well. 

The motors that they used for the stabilizer are so smooth.  When recording a video you do not see the camera shake or jitter.  When the motors move there is no sound or jumping.  Its very comfortable to hold for long periods of time or you can even use the provided stand.  The overall feel is very premium and of a high quality. 

The app that you download to use the stabilizer is easy to use.  It also offers different photo/video modes along with tips on how to take great videos.  The app quickly connects to the stabilizer via Bluetooth.  There is also no lag from the app to the stabilizer, everything happens quickly.  

I'm a novice photographer, but this thing is so much fun to use and I can see taking it with me on vacation.  My favorite thing to use is the follow/tracking feature.  I was able to hold the stabilizer and it was able to track my dog running around the house.  I was amazed at how easily and quickly it kept on the dog.  This is by far my favorite feature of the stabilizer.  It will make taking videos a lot of fun and easy.

This is my first stabilizer and overall I love it!  I cannot wait to show it off to people and use it for videos.  The DJI is worth every penny as it is such a premium device.

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment:
[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] The DJI Osmo Mobile 6  Gimbal is a very high quality, well designed mobile stabilizer.

But as an owner of the Google Pixel 6 I have to point out some of the negatives right from the start.

First, the DJI MIMO app is not available in the Google Play Store. In order to download the app you must go into settings and allow download and installation of apps from unknown sources. That’s right, you must download an app from a Chinese company directly, without being verified by Google. This of course is accompanied by a warning that downloading this app may cause harm to your device and other apps on your device.  Not very comforting. In addition, not all features work on Android phones. Each phone model is different and therefore this may vary by device.

Also, I found that my phone was hotter in the Osmo than it is normally when its in camera mode, and the battery drained much quicker.

One other issue is the magnetic clip holder. It goes on the Pixel phone on top of the volume switch. If placed exactly in the middle of the phone it presses on the down volume switch and turns the volume all the way down.

The focus scroll wheel is also not functional with my Pixel phone.

The device itself is very high quality, very ergonomically designed. It is very well balanced in the hand and does not cause hand fatigue. All buttons and switches are placed within easy reach.

DJI has videos in the app to fully explain the operation of each switch.

In the box you get the magnetic phone clip, the stabilizer unit, an attachable tripod and a charging cable.

After you download the app, the Osmo 6 will automatically turn on when you attach the phone and off when the phone is removed.

One of my favorite features is face lock while in video. Your phone will lock on your face and follow you around. You can place the phone in the Osmo with the tripod, put it on a flat surface and record yourself while moving, and the camera will follow you. A push of a button will automatically switch between portrait and landscape.

Image stabilization is of course a main reason for buying this device and it performs better than any phone by itself.

There is a scroll wheel for zooming in and out as well as a button for switching between video and photo.

There are way too many features to mention, however DJI does a great job of explaining the functions in video and with hints that appear on the screen.

I would love to recommend this device, and I would to any iPhone user. But if you are an Android user I would weigh the positives and negatives before purchasing. I don’t know why DJI has put Android users in this situation and I hope that this situation changes sooner rather than later. This could easily be a5 start review if not for the software issues for Android.

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment:
[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] The Osmo Mobile 6 is a very fun smartphone gimbal stabilizer packed with great features to help you capture smooth, creative footage and fun photos. I like that a lot of what the gimbal has to offer is right at my finger tips. Changing modes, camera orientation, and angles is a click of a button or a push of the joystick away from personal customization. Each mode focuses on customizing which axis has priority over the movement of the camera. More on the modes below.

DJI MIMO APP
To get the most out of the DJI Osmo Mobile 6, I suggest downloading the DJI Mimo app which allows you to use all the buttons to their fullest potential. Using the DJI Mimo app will unlock these additional button or handle features:
Switch between front and back camera
Switch between photo and video mode
Use the focusing or zoom wheel
Use the record button

The features listed above are not available to use with my Google Pixel Camera App. Here are the Osmo Mobile 6 buttons or handle features you can use WITHOUT the Mimo app (say like with your phone’s native camera app, these will just inherently work if the gimbal is on and the phone is mounted properly): 
Joystick
Switching between Landscape or Portrait orientation
Changing Modes
Re-centering with trigger button
Using the trigger to “lock” the view

The DJI Mimo app is very neat. I really like the subject-follow feature because it essentially allows you to set the camera down and let the app/camera follow your movement even without handling the gimbal itself. This is possible with the included mountable tripod which is an awesome accessory that’s included with this kit. My phone is not compatible with the focusing feature so the wheel on the side only allows me to zoom, not smoothly I might add, but not a dealbreaker.

EXTENDING FEATURE
This gimbal also extends so you can get high up drone-like shots or very low shots. It’s like a selfie stick, but better because it’s also a gimbal! The only downside to this is that because of the extendable feature, you have to be careful when taking it to amusement parks as they often don’t allow extendable devices like this one.

4 GIMBAL MODES
Out of the 4 modes, the one that’s more “general” or easiest to work with is the first one: Follow mode. It’s going to either pan up or down, left or right, depending on which way you move the camera, and it won’t “roll” sideways. 

The second mode: Tilt Lock, will do just that, lock the tilt and allow you to pan left or right with natural hand movement. If you want to change the angle of the tilt in Tilt Lock mode, just use the joystick to bring the camera’s view up or down. 

The third mode: FPV will actually follow any movement on all 3 axes, so you get more dynamic or creative shots with this mode as it will “roll” (turn the camera sideways) as you’re following a subject. 

The fourth mode: SpinShot allows you to naturally “roll” the camera sideways while still facing a subject, as well as lets the joystick rotate the camera as well, whereas in the other modes, the joystick is moving the camera angle up, down, left or right. SpinShot allows the camera to tilt sideways. To get a visual of what this looks like, look straight ahead then lean your head to one side like you’re putting your ear to your shoulder, and keep looking straight. This is the “roll” effect I’m talking about.

OVERALL
I love playing with this gimbal. I take it to local music shows and plan to take it to a festival to get some smooth footage and fun pictures. It’s great for people who like to film videos whether it’s for an event or an artistic video piece. This gimbal has plenty of modes to work with to get super creative shots or just get nicely stable footage. I’ve only had to charge it once so far and I’ve used it a few times. There’s a nice indicator screen that shows you modes, battery level, and will let you know with a red light above the battery indicator if the magnet is not secured properly. I can definitely recommend this gimbal to anyone who likes video tech or looking to gift it.

comment:
[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] This is a very cool add on for your smart phone, it takes advantage of the ebst camera in the house with it's easy to use gimbal and the awesome DJI mimo software. The quality out of the box is very apparent, the material feels good, the buttons are responsive, the foldable hinges seem durable and the magnetic hold is secure. product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment:
[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] The DJI Osmo 6 Phone Stabilizer Gimbal is a handheld device that using a gyro-type system, will let you place your smartphone on it, and it stabilizes the phone for photos and videos while you are handholding the device.  As you move, it moves with you, but your phone seems to “float” in it’s holder, not moving at all unless you get carried away and move too much or too fast.  But with normal panning, walking, even jogging, your photos and videos will remain pretty much motion/jerky free.

The Osmo 6 has a main body that consists of a hand grip and varied controls, along with an arm that extends (which turns it on when you do so).  A strong magnetic disk with stretching clips wraps around your phone and then sticks onto this arm, so you can use it while moving around.  The arm itself also has a telescoping feature so you can extend it and get more than 8 inches of reach as well (think of it as a souped-up selfie stick if you want).  A separate tripod attachment screws onto the bottom and has three legs you can extend – this way, you can use the Gimbal as a tripod for video, photo, podcasts, etc.  It’s a standard mount so you can also use many normal sized tripods as well.

You need to download the DJI app for best results.  Once installed and set up, your phone connects to the Osmo 6 via Bluetooth, and when you magnetically snap it onto the Gimbal, the app auto-launches on your phone.  There’s a variety of tutorials teaching you how to use the device, and it connects to your phone's album(s) with permission, so you can use it through the app.  It WILL work without the app, but I found some of the features to work in a clunky way without it.

The controls on the hand grip allow you to pan the camera, back and forth, up and down, control zoom and focus, flip from the main back camera to the front camera, re-center the phone, and track subjects of your choosing, and more.  Some buttons have more than one function based on how many times you click them.  I will say, the sheer number of click combinations for different functions at first seems a bit overwhelming and you will find yourself referring to the manual many times to remember what does what.  It’s not the best experience in my opinion, but in time, all of the combinations should begin to sink in.  

The Osmo 6 does work as advertised.  Panning at a fairly good clip, it keeps my video steadier than I can do by hand, even if I use the phone’s built-in stabilizer.  Likewise, if taking still photos and you are moving a bit, it will help keep things steady hence, sharper photos and videos. I have a medical condition that sometimes makes it hard to remain super steady, and this definitely made a huge difference. I’ve only seen one or two millisecond hiccups where it stalled, but it hasn’t been common.  The motor is not loud.  Battery life is very good, and it charges via a USB-C port on the side of the main body.  A battery icon on the main body tells you when you’re low.  

This isn’t the type of device that every person with a phone will want to invest in or spend the money for, especially if you really just use your phone for casual photography with an occasional video.  But if you are more serious about your pics and vids and take a good number of both, and/or you like to experiment with podcasting or making more semi-pro videos, then it’s a worthy investment to make your media look more professionally done.  Not perfect, but recommended if you need it.

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment:
[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] The DJI Osmo Mobile 6 is DJI’s latest phone gimbal promising an all in one experience. This gimbal combines a gimbal and selfie stick into one along with DJI’s Mimo app for “efficient shooting, editing, and sharing” which may or may not be your actual experience. After a few days I have to say this gimbal isn’t for everyone. 

In the Box:

-	Osmo Mobile 6 Gimbal
-	Magnetic Phone Clamp
-	Gimbal Tripod
-	Power Cable
-	Storage Bag

Setup:

For best results, you need to download the DJI app which is where you might start to notice a different perspective in the overall user experience whether you are an IPhone or Android user. For Android, you must download the app via APK (because the Google Play Store does not have an official app to download). The APK warns you that the file may contain viruses and harm your device. Chances are it will not but it’s not something you feel overly enthused about.

After the app is installed, the phone connects to the gimbal via Bluetooth. The phone itself sits inside a magnetic clamp and then snaps on and off of the gimbal. The process is very simple to get the phone on and off of the gimbal however the clamp may sit in a problem spot depending on your phone design. This varies greatly but if you have buttons in the center or just off center of the edges on your phone, this may be a problem.

The bottom of the gimbal features a threaded mount to install the tripod mount. Simply screw it on and off and it acts as a tripod. If you want to use the selfie stick function of the gimbal just pull the end up/out and you can use the gimbal in an extended mode.

The buttons on the hand grip gimbal portion allow you to control most functions of the gimbal/phone app without using the touch screen of the phone itself. You can change modes of the type of shot you want, pan, tilt, control zoom and focus, flip camera views, re-center your phone, and activate/disable active track, etc. If you double click some buttons it will act as different functions. If you are familiar with other DJI products, this will seem very intuitive.

Usage:

The gimbal does exactly what it claims. It will keep the phone nearly perfectly steady with little effort on your end. This will be substantially better than any optical/digital stabilization in your phones camera from the factory. Sometimes if may often work better with the gimbal if you disable any stabilization on your phone while using the gimbal but this is optional and your experience may differ depending on the phone. 

My only issue that I ran into was the pivot point for the selfie stick always was at the wrong angle when you put it back down into its regular position. So the bottom motor would rub on the edge of the plastic body. It does feel quite delicate when you are pull and pushing on the stick to raise and lower it but I suppose that’s what it was designed to do. 

Overall:

The DJI Osmo Mobile 6 is a great gimbal for your phone to achieve cinematic like footage with excellent stabilization. My biggest complaints are more to do with the Mimo app rather than the gimbal itself. For years, DJI have not released official apps on the Play Store for some reason. I wish they would release an official build so people don’t have to feel like they are letting access to their phone via an APK. In addition, the features should be better optimized for the Android platform like they are for IPhone users. Outside of this, I believe it is a very useful tool for those looking for an affordable all-in-one type of device to create better content.

product_name: DJI Osmo Mobile 6 Smartphone 3-Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Grey
comment:
The Osmo Mobile 6 includes several shooting modes, including ActiveTrack 4.0, which allows the gimbal to automatically track and follow a subject, and Gesture Control, which allows you to take selfies or start/stop recording by making hand gestures.

In terms of battery life, the Osmo Mobile 6 has a run time of up to 7.5 hours, which is an improvement over its predecessor. It also features a USB-C port for charging your phone while you're using the gimbal.

Overall, the DJI Osmo Mobile 6 is an excellent smartphone gimbal that offers a great balance of features, ease of use, and portability. If you're looking for a way to improve the quality of your smartphone video footage, the Osmo Mobile 6 is definitely worth considering.
