The AliveCor Mobile ECG is a very easy to use and very convenient device to monitor my heart function. It is reassuring to know that it is always ready to do an ECK and that my device has proven to be a reliable measuring tool. I am impressed by its accuracy and this was again proven when a friend of mine who has AF recently tested my device.

I purchased this machine because I have had heart issues for over 20 years, right now I go in and out of Afib and also Vtach. This machine will allow me to send EKG’s to my doctor at a moments notice. I love the ease of doing it by only placing 2 fingers on each side. Thankful that this has fda approval and used by so many doctors. Thank uou!

I always have trouble trying to use anything that connects with my phone.
Not this time, got the app. put my fingers on the probe and it did the rest.
worked perfect right from the get go.
Records and stores the EKG. and retrieving it for my doctor is easy.
Excellent device for those of us who are not up to speed with today's electronics.

Don't  know  how  to set it up. You need to use an appand I have no idea how to do it and have no one to  help me
I  asked  when I  was in the store and bought it and I  was told that geek squad  would  have to do it but they were too busy and couldn't  help me. This is a heart monitor  that I  need for health reasons. I  am very unsatisfied

I really need this device, but I don't go backwards in technology. I have the Android Samsung Galaxy 8, since the 7 was discontinued for its tendency to catch fire. The Samsung Galaxy 8 has been around for a long time now and yet you're still not compatible with it? How can you sell a product that's so far behind? Are customers supposed to go out and buy an old phone from some old phone website? I don't even know if I could buy an old phone just for this purpose, although I suppose I would if the old phone were cheap enough. PLEASE make it a priority to be compatible with the technologies that people are actually using, now. Not what people were using 2 years ago. That just doesn't work. You have to keep up. I'm so frustrated because I really, really do need this device. What should I do? Maybe you ought to sell the older phones at a reduced price so people can buy your device? It's a way around the problem.....
-Stacey ... waiting and worrying

The KardiaMobile is okay, but it cannot diagnose anything except afib.  Since it communicates with a smartphone via ultrasonic signal, it is subject to noise that people cannot hear.  The newer, more expensive model is much better, but I lost mine and now they won't sell me a new one without a monthly subscription that I don't want or need.

This device is totally worth the money. So easy to use. Small enough to keep in my purse. I do wish it offered a case to hold it. I record my readings for my cardiologist and he recommends having it. I have A fib and it always tells me what’s going on.  Holds your history and so easy for the doctor to read. Wish I had known about it sooner!

Amazing device! Have recommended to many patients with arrhythmia a requiring checking e.g. atrial fib or SVT patients.  Very portable, seamless connectivity to phone and available in any format.  Very affordable too... Essentially for less than cost of a holter you have a continuous ability to check rhythm anytime.  Cannot be without it!!

I bought this product to check my heart beat as I experienced some irregular heart beat last December. I am very confident with the readings given and with the ability to comment on the results and to give a detailed context on each reading. Along with taking my blood pressure regularly, I am now confident concerning my daily heart health.

I submitted $ for my EKG and then I was informed that the reading would appear with in the next 24 hours to me that's a joke find having a heart attack I want to know before tomorrow I think if you want to charge For a quick meeting it should be a quick reading.  Otherwise I think it's a good product and is very helpful as far as it goes .

This appears to work for its intended purpose but to me, it is difficult to use.  It is a come-on to get you to enroll in a program that is supposedly medically supervised.  It is hard for me to get my fingers positioned correctly to create a good signal.  The next time I see my cardiologist I will see what he says.  This was a gift to me.

Very cool tool to use for heart monitorization efforts.  The data is actually recognized by your Cardiologist and can be used as sufficient data to detect any high level issues.  Notice how I mentioned "high level", this is not a real EKG, but maybe 25% of that capability to warrant a real EKG if out of sequence heart beats are discovered.

Is there a Windows-based compatible tool for use with a PC for those of us who don't have an Apple or Android device? My computer (and Windows phone, for that matter) are both Bluetooth compatible and could use the same app. It seems like adding a Windows-based app for use with PCs would make your device accessible to a much larger crowd.

I like the case, but I wish the edges were smoothed out.  Along the bottom and top, when I hope my phone sideways, it's rubbing on my finger and is sharp enough to cut my hand.  I will probably have to file it down to keep from irritating.  Otherwise, I like how it holds the Kardia Mobile without making the profile of the phone too thick.

If I could give this device 10 stars I would. It has saved my life multiple times over the past year. I have Afib quite a bit and so for me this is a must have. It has been 100% accurate that my heart doctors highly recommend it for there patients. It’s the best 30 seconds of your life. If you’re normal or you need to go to the hospital.

My EP recommend that I purchase the Kardia Mobile so that I could periodically send him EKG's indicating whether I am in A-Fib or A-Flutter.  It is so easy to do and sending him a pdf file allows him to track my situation.  My heart ablation procedure is scheduled for next week and the Kardia Mobile will also provide post procedure data.

Seems to be an accurate EKG monitor.  Easy peasy in taking readings.  I gave it a 4 rating however, because initially the advertisement stated this monitored three different heart conditions.  It only monitors your EKG......UNLESS you purchase the upgrade.  Still worth the money if you are interested in only keeping a record of your EKG,

I purchased a replacement Kardia and it showed "No Service" when I tried to use it.  Customer Support spent a lot of time helping me and giving me suggestions.  Once my phone and Kardia were compatible, I love it.  My cardiologist is the one who suggested I buy this and gave me his email to send reports when necessary.  Very comforting.

I only was able to get this to work for me a few times.  All other times I get an "unreadable recording" message.  I looked at all the tips for trouble shooting this, and followed them all, but still can not get a reading.  Other members of my family can get a reading, but for whatever reason, which I simply can not figure out, I can't.

I got the KardiaMobile last week and am so impressed! It took less than 5 minutes to download the app, create an account and take my first tracing. As a former cardiac care nurse, I am just amazed by the quality of the EKG and thrilled that I now have a chance to "catch" my fleeting arrhythmia. It's just an absolutely brilliant device.

When it works, it is great.  But mine quit working on numerous occasions and I would put it away for weeks and then try it again.  Sometimes it would then work and sometimes it worked briefly.  When it was functioning properly I loved it and it was very helpful.  I have PVCs  and it was very useful in monitoring my variable heartbeat.

The AliveCor-KardiaMobile personal EKG monitor works as advertised. It was very easy to download and set up the app on my phone. Getting an accurate EKG reading was also very easy. I was thinking of getting an Apple Smart Watch solely for its EKG monitoring ability, but because I now have this KardiaMobile, I don't need to spend $400!

As a Cardiologist, I find this device invaluable for quickly documenting a patient's heart rhythm, without needing to connect a full electrocardiograph. For patients with heart rhythm disturbances, being able to tell quickly what is going on helps with a sense of security and ability to transmit concerning rhythms to their physician.

I used to have Kardia mobile 6L and it was very good it can connect with the phone without any problem however i lost it so i ordered this time Kardia mobile but i was shocked by how it work it transmits High frequency notes to the mic of the phone which limits the device to be away from the phone!! And that was not convenient to me.

The Kardia Mobile device works great, unless you keep your expensive phone in a waterproof case because the Kardia communicates with your phone using sound waves, which do not go through solid plastic apparently. Great device, but I cannot use it without removing my phone from the case. As a plumber, my phone must be kept in such a case for obvious reasons.

I went to Urgent Care with chest pains, I had a set of Kardia EKG's and the Dr. and nurses there were surprised and excited to see my heart when it was in pain. The ambulance crew was just as surprised, they handed them to the ER Dr. at the hospital and he sat down and thanked me for having them and went through them with with me. They went into my records!

My cardiologist highly suggested I get a Kardia. So I did, these things are the best thing since sliced bread! I can keep up with how my heart's doin when i feel like somethin is goin on without an ER visit. This thing as saved me money. Also, i can send the recording to my Cardiologist without goin to his office. Best money I've spent in a very long time!

Suspected my wife to have Paroxysmal AF. Several 24 Hour Holter failed to detect. Detected one short run of clearcut AF during her complaint of palpitation. Taking into consideration the frequency and length of her complaint, her Hypertension and DM and enlrged LA on Echo and her brother and sister with chronic AF my  colleagues agrees to start her on NOAC

I have been using Kardia since 2015 due to multi focal tachy-arrhythmias; this device has been life saving for me and I highly recommend it.
It is easy to use
Kardia app is able to store vital medical and prescription info that is easily accessed by emergency responders
Its easy to change the battery
The customer service is always excellent and supportive

Perfect on the go monitor for me. I don't need constant monitoring, but I do know that when I need to record "something funny", I can get a quick recording off to my doctor. Luckily for me, nothing more than a quick pacemaker reprogramming couldn't fix. Having it to record what I can't explain in words, other than a funny feeling, makes it worth it to me.

Being that I have Afib, I check my BPM 3 times daily. My readings were over 130. Went to my cardiologist with my printouts. Their EKG displayed about the same as the Kardia did. I’m now scheduled for a stress test. I had a holster monitor for a week with results to be discussed. Now probable Amblation surgery in the very near future.
Thank you Kardia!!!

If you happen to have sensitive hearing, this device is useless as when it is used it emits a piercing scream for some.  It does not bother me (I cannot hear it), but if a coworker next to my room is there, she goes nuts and starts screaming at me to "turn it off", i.e. stop using it. Gives her instant migraines - so who knows what it is doing to others.

This is an excellent way to diagnose a cardiac arrhythmia at home and be able to send the recording to your doctor. I was in atrial fibrillation and I was quite sure that it was.  But until my cardiologist got the reading we could not be sure.  I did not want to go to the ER to get an EKG. Now I can monitor my rhythm from home. An incredible invention!

There's no ecosystem built around the product and beyond a point, its utility tapers off for someone with no major chronic cardiac issues. The product may also benefit from a bit of gamefication. I wonder if AliveCor can engage in a manner similar to Spire and connect to moments of stress. Maybe even collaborate with Spire to build a unified solution ?

It is re-assuring to check periodically and get the normal result.  My doctor advised that it may not be able to detect A Flutter, which is what I had after A Fib was detected.  But their is a treatment for A Flutter and in about 30% of the cases, when you have that treatment it also seems to prevent going back into A Fib.  So far so good.  Thank you.

I had a scare:  suddenly developed a-fib.  The cardiologist shocked my heart, and it’s back in normal rhythm, but I wanted to keep track of it.  Ordered Kardia and it came in two days.  I did a test of it, it worked perfectly;  leaving next week for a month in Europe, and feel much more at ease because I can keep track of my heart rate with my Kardia!

Very convenient to monitor possible afib symptoms and send to doctor, but electrodes are super sensitive and must be held very, very still and there must be no tension in fingers and arms. I also find that the other recommended body sites to pick up the signal are useless with my device. Only my index and middle fingers of both hands really work well.

Purchasing the KardiaMobile device was a great decision! Having recent heart issues, this device allows me to take a quick look at the current rhythm and rate, even stores those results for my next doctors appointment. I do have prior experience in reading telemetry strips, so I get peace of mind seeing my heart rhythm on screen. What a handy device!!

Your AliveCor app and mobil ECG unit have been very useful in diagnosing my wife's AFIB.  We recorded her first episode while traveling out of the country and were able to print the ECG at home upon our return.  Our cardiologist was then able to make the diagnosis and start treatment.    Thank you very much for such an important medical advancement.

I am a Family Physician an I bought KardiaMobile with the hopes of being able to check patients with irregular pulses for atrial fibrillation without always needing to do an EKG.  I found that doing this in exam rooms was often challenging because of interference from other devices.  In addition my KardiaMobile totally failed after about 18 months.

Question: I have a level 2 hypertension with high-blood pressure ranging from 150/110 regularly.  And im with the risk of stroke, and im worried. I would like in any way to monitor my health specially Afib. The problem is I live in Dubai. Is there any way I can have this great product that I will now will be a big help to monitor my status.

Thanks

I successfully used this ECG on medical mission trips to Africa and Colombia where it has actually helped in life-saving events. However you changed it so that the device only works where contact with the internet is available. Thus it is no longer useful to me since I go where there is no internet. Could you please provide a work around for this?

It can be really hard to use.  You're supposed to just put your fingers on the pads, but 90% of the time, it just doesn't register.  Or it starts working and then I'll have only two seconds to go, and then it stops and tells me that it was interrupted and I have to do it again - and that will happen ten times in a row (even though I didn't do anything to interrupt it).  Or it just doesn't work at all - the pads don't register my fingers as existing at all.  It's incredibly frustrating.  The other thing I'm confused about it what it's really supposed to do.  I mean, so far, it just tells me that I have "normal sinus rhythm", but what else?  Can't you give me any more information than that?  I requested a cardiologist's review, but never got anything back about it.  I feel like I spent an awful lot of money on something that only works some of the time and so far only tells me that I'm "normal" about one thing.  I thought it would do more.

KardiaMobile is a great device to have! My husband hadn’t been feeling well, always complaining of strange sensation in his chest.  So, I bought the device just to have and my husband was able to detect that he was in a.fib His rhythm was confirmed by a 12-Lead EKG. I was impressed with the accuracy of the device! I would recommend this to anyone.

I have stopped using it as it failed to operate properly over time.  As new updates came out, the performance deteriorated to the point that I could not get meaningful results anymore.  

It was good when it worked and I found it to be useful to track my heart.  However, now it collects dust in a draw as I found it too unreliable to use anymore.

This reads heart activity in high detail, so much so that it might qualify to work with some folks with heart disease. Doing so requires a paid subscription but generally could save hours of waiting room time and the expense of drs office visits. 
This being winter, my dry skin gave it trouble reading my heart activity. The battery is replaceable.

This has been an outstanding purchase. It does give correct reading and the opportunity to have information to show my cardiologist and primary care giver what my heart has been doing at times during the day. I can keep on going records and be aware of any and all A-Fibs issues. I would recommend this product to anyone with heart related issues.

Kardia Mobile is an amazing tool that sticks to the back of your Iphone. You download an app called Kardia. I have heart issues where my heart starts racing frequently. I simply click on the App and it will record an EKG of my heart. It will give you a diagnosis. You can email them to your MD directly from app. Two years ago I had several episodes of Atrial Fibrillation.  I emailed them to my cardiologist who immediately started me on a blood thinner. AFIB is very dangerous and causes strokes. This device has saved my life. Most people who have strokes do not know they have AFIB. Having the EKG evidence not only got me on the blood thinners, but I am being treated at the Cleveland Clinic for a surgery to eliminate the AFIB. It is amazing that I caught the AFIB. None of my holter monitors had found it. Now I am on a path at one of the finest heart hospitals in the world. Thank you for inventing this. I have recommended it to so many friends.

The Alivecor has been a tremendous help for me in tracking my episodes. In fact, my doctor mentioned that he wished more of his patients had AliveCor.  Alivecor should also consider having an attachment plate with the case for future upgrades as the one I have for my Iphone 5s. A detailed  explanation of the BFx would also be much appreciated.

After my husband's heart attack and triple bypass surgeries, we wanted to keep track of his heart rate and rhythm. I never dreamed that an ECG instrument could be so affordable and easy to use. It not only gave us peace of mind, it was helpful to show the cardiologist and cardiac rehab people. It's an amazing technological world we live in. This was well worth the money.

I purchased the KardiaMobile two weeks ago.  I have persistent AFib most of the time, with occasional periods when I am out of AFib, although I am unable to detect when in AFib. The technology of this device is incredible.  AliveCor could not say if it was compatible with my LG model G7 ThinQ phone because they had not tested the device with that specific phone.  Regardless, I purchased the device and it is compatible with my phone as well as with my wife's IPhone.  The device is easy to set up, and fast and easy to operate.  The results compare favorably with results from EKG in cardiologist office.  Most of my readings  are indicated to be Possible AFib, with occasional Unclassified readings.  Readings for my wife, who does not have any known heart issues, are indicated to be Normal.  I email the charts to my cardiologist on a weekly basis.  I have a friend who has AFib, and has used this device for a long time.

I can double check my cardiac tracing to confirm or deny my a fib.  I can show it to my Doctor a great little tool and the app was the easiest one I have ever used.  I enter my vital signs including the EKG in my kardia app on my I phone in the diary.  Print them off and show them to doctor.   Its great for the Older people that have developed an abnormal cardiac rythem.

My wife was diagnosed with A FIB while registering for a minor surgical procedure. That was 6 months ago. After 3 cardioversions and 1 ablation, and on the advice of her doctor,  I purchased this device. It has worked flawlessly. The app is loaded on her iPad and there have been no issues with it. I highly recommend that anyone with hear rhythm issue utilized this tool.

As a former Paramedic, I am experienced at ECG interpretation. I purchased AliveCor because I was curious about the functionality and technology. In my opinion, the data captured and displayed is comparable to devices costing thousands more, such as those used on an ambulance. Not a substitute for 9-1-1 when in doubt, but a helpful tool to supplement a physicians care.

Absolutely a great device! It brings me peace of mind being about to see my rhythm and know  when I need to worry, seek attention, or just rest and monitor.  The only thing I can think of constructive is that I have to put a piece of tape on the sensor to keep it from popping out of its holder that attached to my phone.  If they could improve that- it would be perfect!

Today is 8-7-16.  I received my Kardia Mobile device 7-19-16 in the afternoon.  I sent the initial diagnostic EKG as instructed.  When I awoke the next morning, my results had been returned and I was ready to record as needed. 

I had a follow up appt with my heart PA on 7-26-16 and she was impressed with its ease of use and its accuracy.  (Unfortunately, I have yet to get their code so I can send an EKG to my heart doctor.) On 7-28-16 evening, it caught an A Fib episode (209 bpm) with a day's worth of 'unclassified' recordings before this episode.  

I am trying hard not to become obsessed with my heart issues and go about my day as usual.  But, knowing we can catch an episode and perhaps pinpoint a specific area for the upcoming 'mapping' ablation is very comforting.  I have had no problems with recording or the device saving the recordings.  It has worked as advertised and then some.  Congrats on a great product!

I went for my biannual check up only to be told that I had A-Fib and it was confirmed on an EKG. I took the shock treatment and everything has been fine since. However, I was concerned that since the episode 9 months ago was silent I would never know when another silent attack would happen.  Thus I invested in AliveCor and I sleep well knowing that I do not have A-Fib.

I recently had a hard attack and, having seen a commercial of this, thought this might be a useful tool to have with me.  I'm able to check my heart rhythms anytime or anywhere. It has become a daily routine for me and only takes under a minute to get my results.  It gives me peace of heart.  I thought $79  was try able.  I'm satisfied and would recommend this product.

I have a-fib, and having this on my phone has really helped.  The a-fib is sporadic, and it helps to be able to get a record of each episode to share with my Doctor.  Now, instead of just telling him "how it felt" I can show him the ecg.  He has been very interested in this device - I would recommend it for anyone who has heart issues....it's been worth every penny!!

Great little device.  Easy to set up and use.  Wikh all of the fitness items I thought this would be a nice addition to keep an eye on my heart.  I haven't had any issues with my heart but in this Covid world of ours i thought it might be nice to have an additional tool in the health shed. My wife, daughters and even grandkids like to see what their rythm is as well.

AliveCor is an outstanding device to confirm as to whether or not my heart is in rhythm.  I see my doctor regularly but between visits I attempt to understand and optimize my workouts, rest & diet in order to minimize my A-Fib episodes.  I have made significant progress while learning.  I would like to see AliveCor's use and information expanded through the development or integration of other devices/applications.  Currently, I use Polar Beat with a Polar H7 bluetooth HR monitor for my workouts.  I wear a Fitbit HR to measure my sleep and daily activity.  I use Lose It! to track my diet/nutrition and finally when I am out of rhythm, I use Pill Monitor to track my medication.  Fitbit, Lose It! and Polar Beat integrate some of each others information which I find useful.  As an example, it would be great if AliveCor could read & utilize Polar's H7 bluetooth heart rate monitor strap during workouts. Keep up the good work!

The unit is rather small I have larger hands and it's difficult to get more then four fingers on it and it seems to take a lot of trying to get it to work . I follow your instructions and wipe it with alcohol pads and still have have to try 3-4 times to get it to work , otherwise I find it to be a useful tool though I am not sure of the readings. I use with my I-pad

I love how we can keep a record of all the readings and the ease with which we can email or share it with our Doctor.I also love the feature where we could add symptoms at the time any episode occurs.Puts me at ease Would recommend it in a second to anyone with undiagnosed A fib, where they can never record it on holter monitir.Alivecor is handy anytime of the day

The app has undergone a few updates since I purchased my monitor. I've found it to be well-organized and thoughtfully designed. Only a couple of wishes for a future release: make it easier to restart a recording run without annotating/saving the present one (in case it's flawed/incomplete/has unwanted artifacts), and the Holy Grail, integration with iOS HealthKit.

I began having heart palpitations, wore a monitor, was recommended to see a cardiologist who didn't think there was a problem. My husband got me a Kardia and suddenly I was able to record an episode myself. I was able to record my pulse increase to 220 bpm and see the irregularities as my rhythm changed from tachycardia to possible atrial fibrillation. After a trip to the emergency room my doctor decided that I did have atrial fibrillation and ordered a stress test. She has been able to adjust medication because I have documentation. I went to the office for a 12 lead ekg Friday morning which was fine, then had a 5 hour episode that evening with possible atrial fibrillation and tachycardia. I was able to see that the pulse stayed at 120-122 bpm most of the time with an occasional rise to 136 and bpm. The peace of mind this small device gives me is worth every dime. I am seriously considering upgrading to the 6 lead Kardia.

This provides great confirmation that my heart is in sinus rhythm, as it should be, or not.  It’s great that I can share strips with my doc, too.  The only thing keeping from rating 5 stars is that the finger electrodes tend to be finicky about picking up.  Customer service seems good, as my order was processed quickly, and I received my unit in just a few days.

I purchased this as a gift for my aging parents, and they liked it! The first EKG they took was automatically sent to a specialist who reviews the results free of charge. They told me they like it.
The only drawback is, it is essentially the same EKG (single lead) that you can get with the Applewatch, so if you’ve got one of those, buying this may be redundant.

It’s unbelievable how technology has come so far and so much over the years . Also it’s incredible how this small device can do what it’s designed to do but it does with amazing accuracy ! A small price to pay to track your health . If you don’t have your health not much else matters ! This purchase was a need and not necessarily a want as far as I’m concerned

If you are looking for episodes of irregular heart beats that last for several minutes at a time, it will be an easy way to document the episodes.  However, if the episodes are short, they may be gone by the time you get your phone and the monitor set up to get a recording.  Best for picking up atrial fibrillation episodes which last for a few minutes or more.

I think the AliveCor worked well. I only wish it could be more responsive at times needed. For example if you have a heart flutter or palpitation your phone might not be immediately accessible. When this occurs you do not capture the rhythm you needed or wanted. I think it should be available on a watch or have a chest band to get the information immediately.

This device gives me a great deal of assurance that what I feel is actually happening with my heart.  If I feel something strange, I can send my ECG to my cardiologist by email AND I have a record of recent ECG's to show any emergency room doctors.  I live over 100 miles from my cardiologist,  but I know that he can direct my care should I have an emergency.

When I was diagnosed with A-Fib in November for 2015,  I did a lot of research, determined to "cure" my A-Fib, without surgery.  I bought my Kardia and methodically tracked my readings.  As I wasn't in persistent A-Fib or having severe symptoms, it wasn't always easy for me to know if I was in or out of NSR.  This made it very difficult for me to determine the things (work stress, diet, physical activity, etc..) that were triggering my A-Fib.  Kardia took the guess work out of it.  Ultimately, I primarily use my Kardia to verify that I am in "possible A-Fib," when I don't feel "right."  Kardia has been a great tool for me to learn/verify my symptoms, and to share real world data with my EP.  

New use for my Kardia:  A few days ago I had a catheter ablation, all went well.  Today I used my Kardia for my first post-ablation reading...so happy to see the word "Normal."  I look forward to tracking many more "Normal" readings.. :)

This devise was recommended for me to get from my Cardiologist. An app on your phone has to be in to work so don't think you can just buy it and use it right away. I am technically challenged so I had to travel to a family member to get it set up. I use it once a day. It says I am OK and it records the results for my doctor to review.  Will see if it works.

My husband's Cardiologist recommend him to get this device after he had surgery for AFib. It let's us know whenever he is feeling off and we take a reading and email it to his doctor if it comes back with irregular heart rate. His doctor then give us a call to review. Give us peace of mind when he feels something and we check and the reading shows all good.

The device was purchased for my 86 year-old sister, so I was hoping for simplicity of operation.  After two days of "absent signal", the original battery was found to be defective.  A new battery produced sporadic images and signal.  Final image was achieved (three-bar registration) ONLY when the device was placed directly on the laptop screen.  An unreliable and discouraging device.

The mobile ECG is very helpful and helps me keep track of my arrhythmia.  I can read ECGs.  I do know when I am having an arrhythmia.  I can feel it.  My arrhythmias have decreased greatly and I only have an occassional bout.  I don't feel I need to do a ECG daily.  I feel like you are pressuring me to run an ECG, when I don't think it is needed.  It is a great device though.  Thanks

I've used my AliveCor to diagnose intermittent afib and to validate my dog's cardiac status (she has a bad pulmonic valve and a PDA). It's very useful for focusing one's attention with data on the right thing.   I'd love it if there was some way to use the AliveCor with an Arduino or other IoT devices. Perhaps I just need to get a mic that can hear in the right range and play around?

It is two years since PVI ablation for asymptomatic PAF and Atrial Flutter. As I no longer take heart medication my EP suggested I use Alivecor  occasionally to check that I am still AF free. As I had few symptoms it was always a worry that I might be in AF without knowing. I check once a week it is quick, easy and puts my mind at rest.  I would recommend Alivecor to anyone with AF.

This incredible little device is perfect for tracking your cardiac activity. My cardiologist asked me to track my cardiac rhythm and blood pressure while we follow the impact of the medications he prescribed to get my A-Fib under control. I told him I had purchased the KardiaMobile device. His response was, “perfect.” “That’ll work!” I think this says a great deal about this device!

I was in the computer business for 40 years and 'user friendly' was rarely more than a sales slogan. Alivecor is easy, intuitive and efficient in every way I can imagine. I rely on this product every day and am reassured that I am not in AFib, but I record the time I take my medications and blood pressure readings in the comments section.  Thank you very much for peace of mind!  Don

Really pretty good - actually, I should say quite good. Don't get it unless you are ready to use it properly, not try and be a cardiologist, or be frightened at what you see. Ok - that's just how it went for me. I didn't want to find out I had heart disease, and had to grow up. But, I'm in health care, so it was easier to read about my disease.
This device is i bit small/unstably on your stomach, and you must have moist fingers or the device never finds "baseline". The mfg must be nuts not giving you some way to steady your fingers, phone and device, and moist fingers.  I'm in the trade, so patient. Woe be new users. But, a thick book, salt water presoaked fingers, and the will to learn some basics. Finally, sending this to an on line cardio seems nuts except AFIB or multiple PVCs, which you need to get to an ER. This requires learning IMHO. And DON'T  take "your" EKG.  IMHO. You'll look like an idiot.

For the most part, this worked well.  I was able to send it to my physician. The App kept asking for a list of my meds which I did not send as I assumed that my MD had them.  There were other questions that I did not answer.  Several weeks ago, my doctor said I did not need to send them any more, but I still get a notice to send it, almost daily.  It is a viable and good addition.

Very helpful, beneficial and i can see how potentially life saving this little technological wonder can be. Its a great instrument to have for anyone with potential cardiovascular concerns or for anyone interested in the health of loved ones or even your own. As a purchase it ranks up there as one of the most practical and meaningful ever done. Very pleased. So far no complaints .

A very useful portable way to get an EKG at any time. The only issues were that the device often needed to be extremely near (right next to) the smartphone and that a reading which said possible fibrillation appeared to be a completely normal reading according to a cardiologist. Otherwise, the reassurance of being able to take unlimited EKGs made the device very worthwhile for me.

I was diagnosed with A.fib a few years ago. As a nurse, clear readings are needed. I was a little skeptical at first, but I connected it to my phone-  the very first tracing was as clear as a bell and of course I was back in Fib. yet had no outward symptoms other than slightly irregular heart beat.  This product is well worth the small amount charged.  Get it!  you wont be sorry.

Device is very sensitive to phone - Kardia relative position & orientation. Simply doesn't work in the majority of positions/ orientations with the Kardia in 4" of the phone (iPhone 11). Works reliably with the phone flat on a table, and the Kardia positioned flat on the table, 0 - 2" from the bottom of the phone. Basic (free) EKG analysis is somewhat limited, doesn't flag PVC's.

I think that found a fix for the Android compatibility issues. Apparently, KardiaMobile uses ultrasonic waves to communicate with the smartphone through the smartphone's microphone. So, I downloaded the SoniControl app from the Android play store and ran the AliveCor app, WHILE the SoniControl firewall was running at the same time. What that firewall does is, it apparently stops Android from blocking those signals. New versions of Android seem to block ultrasonic signals by default. Perfect little device otherwise. 

Just be aware of privacy and security issues with using SoniControl. I recommend that you switch the firewall off, when you are not running the AliveCor app.

My husband has frequent PVCs / bigemeny and it gives us a piece of mind!!!

Very easy to use, once the phone compatibility issue got resolved. We use the minute-long readings. 30 seconds is too short for the cardiologist's review.

Previous app was less sensitive, was more stable drawing EKG lines. This one is less user-friendly, makes you save it, then you have to go in and delete unwanted recordings. Previous app was way better,  you save or not save, and you could just swipe delete recordings that were unwanted.   Unable to edit credit card account with new app. I do like the education section though.

I received my Kardia Mobile and case for iPhone 6 yesterday. After removing backing plate it popped right into cover placed on phone with no issues. Took cover off with little difficulty. Received required evaluation this morning and now I'm good to go. Have to figure out where ekg pdf file is stored so I can submit to my doctor but that's the only issue I have after day one.

I find the AliveCor easy to use even though I did not mounts it permanently to my iPhone.  I just tape it to the phone when I need to use it.  It is so easy to forward the ECG to my physician and he is able to get the information he needs to access my condition.  My physician is the one who recommended the AliveCor to me.  I am very satisfied with the product and the service.

My wife really needs your Kardia Mobile BUT... she has a LG cell phone. We can't replace her phone right now so can you tell me if, and/or when, you might update the compatibility list. Her cell phone is a K7, Model LG-K330 with Android version 5.1.1 (software version K33010f) ??
Her cardiologist told us she really should have this to alert him to her heart status.
Thank you.

I love having this device on my iPhone.  If I think I am having an episode, I just take my EKG wherever I am.  I can email my cardiologist the results and it saves me spending $ in copay to have it done at the doctors office.  The history allows me to see how the A-Fib is progressing - i.e, frequency of episodes, duration, intensity, etc. Again, an amazing gadget.   Love it.

The product does what it claims and is great at helping find AF and giving good ECGs for reassurance. Worth the price. It does seem to get some artifacts in the ECG on a Samsung Galaxy S5 that I didn't get on my previous S3. My doctor loves the fact that I can send a pdf of my ECG to her. If you have heart issues, you should have one of these. And I never travel without it.

This easy to use device can be carried with you on the back of your phone used at any time. The ECG image it produces is diagnostic quality. My cardiologist was quite impressed with it.

I have now upgraded to the 6-lead model (only $50 more) because of the additional information it can provide. That's just for me; the single lead does the job just fine for almost everyone.

I find the AliveCor Mobile ECG very easy and interesting to use.  I have AFib, PVCs and flutter.  Using the ECG I found I also have PACs.  Since purchasing the monitor last June, 2015, I have not had an AFib episode.  I still plan to monitor my heart daily and maybe someday log an AFib episode to see what my heart is actually doing.    I haven't experimented with any ECG position other than my fingers on the electrodes.  Maybe someday I will try the other connection methods.  The only problem I've had with the monitor is extraneous signal interference.  For example, I just returned from a three week cruise and couldn't use the ECG monitor because of the ships interference.  It might not be possible to provide a more stable connection from the ECG to the phone app.  If you can, that would be appreciated.  I don't do any symptom logging because I never have any symptoms aside from the irregular rhythm of my heart.

After completing at least weekly ECG's the device quit functioning,  hence there are no recent recordings. I had AFib which was corrected by an ablation.  The ECG app continued to indicate AFib.  I checked with my cardiologist and he assured me that I was not in AFib and suggested that I disable the AFib detection which I did.  I would like to get the app functional again.

My son has dysautonomia with a fast heart rate. Kardia Mobile makes it easy to get a quick EKG when he is feeling dizzy. It made it very easy to give his doctor the results. Just wish it could record blood pressure too.  Just make sure to have your phone very close to the monitor. When I first got it, I had it too far away from my phone and was not getting a good reading.

I bought the Kardia sensor and a protective jacket for my iphone 6.
The sensor works very well.
The protective jacket does not fit the sensor, and looks to be too thick to fit over the phone if the sensor was in place.  It does fit the phone without the sensor in place.

It looks like an engineer just cut two square holes in a standard jacket and never tried it out.

John

This tool is outstanding. I had A Fib oblation surgery 4 years ago which was successful but occasionally have sinus rhythm with premature ventricular contractions. I feel them & my device immediately confirms. This tool is unbelievably affordable & can help put your mind at easy that your not or perhaps are in an emergency situation. I have had mine for 2 years. LOVE IT.

This is a single lead rhythm strip that you can use to tell if you have afib, now you can do it with your fingers and check yourself for irregularly irregular beats or pay a lot for this bulky thing that attaches to the back of your phone.  I ripped it off my phone after a month because it made it bulky, hard to put into my pockets.  I also don't have afib and didn't like the false reads. Overall very useless.

This is an excellent app!  I like being able to input my medications daily and also the ECG is a great device to check on the heart beat and regularity.  My wife have it since it was first available.  I have upgraded my iPhone and OS when available and AliveCor continues to work flawlessly.  I now have a iPhone 6s.  I would recommend AliveCor to all persons who want to check and maintain health and records.

I wish that your company would remove the commercial showing what you term to be “tachycardia”. Tachycardia would be a heart rate faster than 100 beats per minute. The rhythm strip shown is not tachycardia. Surely if you are selling a medical device that interprets heart rate and rhythm, your ad team should be comprised of people who know basic cardiac rhythms. I would not trust this device for that reason.

I've been having the A-fib very infrequently for quite a while and have told my primary physician.  However, whenever I go to see her, I would always be in sinus rhythm.  Then she told me about AliveCor.  I purchased it over the holidays.  I felt an episode coming and was able to capture the A-fib less than a week after purchasing AliveCor.  Now that I had the proof, I'm seeing a cardiologist for the A-fib.

At first my cardiologist thought it was useless.  Four months later he'd changed his mind and even gave me his personal email address.  I never thought that would happen.  Either someone got to him or he  learned more about it in the mean time.  My GP thought it was a great tool.  He felt the absence of a "P" wave could be a clear indicator that I was in AFIB. All the nurses in cardiac rehab liked it, too.

Since I received this I have had no luck at recording a usable EKG, hard to get and keep a decent signal. when I do get a reading I am pretty sure I am on the verge of death (I'm no Doctor but  I am pretty sure if this reading was true I would be in an ICU) often says electrical interference so I guess is best used in the woods. I do not find this comfortable to use (yes I know you just rest fingers on it)

I have been very pleased with the device as very easy to use and amazing quality rhythm strip for the small size and functionality the iPhone affords. I don't have a cardiac issue but as a physician I recently used it on a neighbor with a hypertensive crisis before I sent her to the ER. Even she was quite impressed with the ease of use. For the money you can't go wrong. Prevention is better than the cure!

Our dog was diagnosed with a-fib and we have been using the single lead KardiaMobile device from home at the suggestion of our vet cardiologist at UC Davis. Device and app are easy to use and understand. Saves historical readings. Readings are easy to share with medical staff.  Great for use on the humans in the house too!  Thanks KardiaMobile for giving us comfort in the care of our fuzzy family member.

The tool is  thorough in providing diagnosis results. Need to try to add atrial flutter. It is a very useful to be able to pay an outside service to get follow up diagnostics quickly and easily and at a fair price. The software and apparatus always work 100 percent reliable. The only improvements would be to broaden the diagnostics. Reporting is clever and useful as are reminders to use to use the tool.

Having instant access to a very portable EKG is life changing. The Kardia Mobile has saved me and my wife a lot of worry, and the expense of unnecessary trips to the ER to confirm my suspicions that my heart flutter was only minor. Very affordable peace of mind for those with episodes of heart flutter, or past episodes of A-Fib that were successfully restored to normal heart rhythm. The Carry Pod is an inexpensive accessory that looks like part of your key chain and makes it even easier to have the Kardia Mobile with you at all times. The Kardia Mobile device will report A-Fib if I have it so I can get immediate medical care.  It also provides me with an EKG that can be emailed to my doctor for reference.  My doctor reminded me to get immediate medical care for severe or persistent flutters, but confirmed that the EKG's I sent to her via email did not show any serious palpitations.

I think the ekg app was very easy to use and was very helpful for me to be able to have some validation of what I was feeling, when I was feeling it. When I started to have a palpitation it was easy to start, sit, relax, and let it record. I liked that the time it measured could be adjusted, events could be starred, and that it was always with me being integrated into a phone case. It's a great design.

I experience heart flutter and odd beats but many times they are not caught by the 30 second display window that the AliveCor app monitors. I wish there were a way to record for a longer period of time like 60 to 120 seconds and then select the 30 second snapshot you want to save. That way I could better catch in the saved report the unusual heartbeats that I am experiencing and show them to my doctor.

I bought this on the recommendation of my nephew and one of my Dr gave me a Scrip.  It kept telling me I had AF so I bought the newer model.  I used it a few times and now this one is giving me AF again.  My VA Dr gave me an EKG immediately when I showed him the first one and he told me why I didn't have AF by explaining the EKG.  This one is no better than the last one and for me was a waste of money!

As a person who has dealt with AFIB low I do not always know when I am in AFIB. AliveCor has let me know when I am in AFIB. I had a second catheter ablation October 30, 2015 and have used Alive Cor to verify that I am no longer in AFIB. Great product that I will continue to use should I feel like I may be experiencing symptoms - although I think my electro-physiologist got it this time. Balloon method.

The first 2 I got didn't work so I was thinking it wasn't a good product, but they were more than willing to send me a new one and send the bad one back at no cost to me. Finally I got one that works great and it has helped me pinpoint exactly what type of arrhythmia I had been experiencing. Even the Dr's have been impressed by it. And the improvements they have made are great! I'm thankful I have it.

It has been extremely comforting to have when you suddenly feel weak or feel like something is not right! My Cardiologist even said "I can use the ECG". Once recorded it can be sent to your doctor and collected on " drop box" so you have access to all your recording history any time, any where and on any device.. The doctor will have access to more real life recordings than were ever possible before!

My AFIB was treated twice with Ablation Therapy and I am currently on an Antiarrhythmic  medication. It is extremely helpful to be able to evaluate a transient event as opposed to persistent AFIB. It also is very reassuring to be able take a routine ECG and determine that all is well.  My cardiologist finds the data I can provide during routine examinations useful for his evaluation of my condition.

I am a retired neurosurgeon who developed AF and had an ablation procedure. I had considerable experience reading EKG's as a flight surgeon in the military. When I developed palpitations I got the App. I have been able to monitor myself, and at times send questionable readings to my cardiologist. Post procedure I have been using it to see that there is no recurrent AF. It  has been invaluable to me.

This small device, and an app on your smart phone, adds peace of mind to those of us walking around with heart decease. Works flawlessly every time and can be set up to share your test results with a/your doctor. Worth every penny. I have recommended this device to others I care about. It's well made, built to last. I've had mine for a couple of years. Purchased on line. I am a male, 76 years young.

It gives you peace of mind. We all know a smart phone is a blessing and a curse. Kardia mobile may be the best use of a smart phone. After a sudden and unexpected arrhythmia episode, my husband treats me like an undetonated grenade. When we were traveling, I didn’t tell him I felt unwell, because he would have panicked. Now my cardiologist can review my results from any place that has cell service!

I have Afib and Aflutter.  I have used a Kardia for several years and misplaced it. I experienced an Aflutter event and not having the Kardia made it impossible to offer information to my Cardiologist. With the Kardia, I am able to send the activity, so decisions can be made of what to do. It has been an invaluable tool over a number of years.  AliveCor sent a replacement and we are back on track.

Saw that I was in AFIB and sought help.  BPM was 150. Day of Ablation I decided to bring in my device to check against the hospitals machine. It was exciting to see my KardiaMobile match the expensive virtual signs machine beat per beat on both the BPM and EKG.  For the first time today my Kardia read Normal heart rate with 76 BPM. Thank you to everyone who worked to make this life saver possible.

My wife experiences SVT events and I purchased it for her use. She has used it daily to build a historical log of readings to refer to and to ensure that she is familiar with using the device. We have found it easy to use and to create and export the reports. It's small size and simple operation assure that it will be available to capture her next event! Thank You for producing this valuable tool.

As a 65 year old male, I have concerns about heart disease.  I have a benign ventricular arrhythmia which, other than feeling the skips, is asymptomatic.  I am a doctor and can read my own EKG's and it's reassuring to me to see that nothing new is going on.  If there was, it would allow me to immediately seek medical advice. I would like the capability to email the strips to myself for my records.

Better before the app was updated. Asks every time if it is me, can I change its almost always me, if not I can make a note. Seems not to have As much electrical interference with my 6S as it did with my 4S, But not as sensitive. Sometimes I make a recording & like to discard immediately the only option is to save it, then to trash it (if I could discard, then I could re start a better recording)

I am a retired ER RN and kept flipping into an unknown very rapid arrhythmia that never got caught on clinic EKGs in doctor visits. I figured it was probably a PAT but too rapid to count. I bought your 6L Alivecor Portable EKG unit and SO easy to use and I can read EKGs. I did a baseline and it was a Regular sinus rhythm at rate of 58 which is normal for me. . One Saturday night ( so a weekend) I flipped into the weird arrhythmia and quickly got an EKG and it was A-Fib at rapid capture rate of 132 to 150. It lasted 5 hours. I called snd sent both normal and abnormal EKGs to my cardiologist on Monday morning and he put me on a blood thinner to prevent stroke until I could see him in 3 weeks ( which was totally fine and good care). I have had a couple followup procedures to check out my heart further and possible causes. Thank you Alivecore. Unit more than triple paid for itself in one use.

Easy to use. Has helped me figure out when I was and was not in a-fib.  I now know what it feels like and can confirm it easily.  I've had a couple of cardiac ablations and this gizmo helps me to track my progress as I heal from the latest ablation.  When I see my cardiologist Or the NP I can show  them the ekg with the date, time and symptoms.  Invaluable for communicating what's been happening.

Works perfectly every time.  Love this. I have an OMRON blood pressure cuff and app.  The OMRON app stores both my bp readings but also my AliveCor EKG readings as well. No monthly charge.  No more wondering if your heart is in sinus rhythm or not. You can take all your readings to your doctor in one app.  You can also store your EKG readings in the AliveCor app on your phone for no charge also.

The AliveCor ecg is an excellent tool for assisting in managing heart-related illnesses.  For instance, my wife and I both use this instrument for direct and quantitative assessment of atrial fibrillation.  Our cardiologist is an enthusiastic supporter of its use.  He reviews the stored records in detail as part of each of our appointments with him and thus knows exactly what has been going on.

I am 45 yr old male that had a heart transplant in 2013.  This amazing product is peace of mind for me between my clinic appointments with my transplant team.  It is super easy to record your data and save each ECG.  I am convinced this technology will help maintain people's health as well as having the opportunity to prevent illness with proactive measurements. Keep up the great work AliveCor!

This is an amazing and handy device.  It is remarkably convenient, accurate enough, and very reassuring.  I have shown it to many doctors, who were at first skeptical, then impressed, and many friends with fibrillation.  I mostly use it for self-monitoring, just to confirm what I have learned to recognize as (now only occasional) episodes, since I utilize medication.  Thanks for the innovation!

I was excited to purchase your product but was forced to return it. Your list of compatible phones is very limited and includes only one LG phone and several Samsung phones that are no longer available. Your phone list is too heavily favoring  Apple phone. Also, it was difficult downloading the app--turn this on that off, etc. before you can set up your product. Great product, poor execution.

I love this personal portable Kardia mobile ekg detector. My Husband’s heart rhythm goes into Afib and he had half his ablation done and waiting for the other side of his heart to be done. We can check his heart rate on my phone app but this little device works with the phone and besides giving heart rate and blood pressure it tells whether your heart is in rhythm. Fantastic and easy to use!!

Hi: I used to do the ECG tracking but fell out of the habit and stopped altogether.  I don't have any heart issues so don't have a personal incentive for doing the tracking.  Having to take my phone case off and then put it back on to use the ECG was getting annoying and so this is why I stopped.  Wish there could be a way to not remove my case -- I would probably not have stopped recording.

I have a history of A-Fib.  Having a portable EKG device that shows heart rate and diagnoses via your phone can be a great asset.  This two finger analyzer is not it.  8 time out of 10 it comes back as “interference” unable to read, even though you are sitting quietly at your kitchen table.  The “Need Help” position is not helpful.  I am returning mine.  I need something that actually works.

The Alivecor Mobile ECG works really well for me, it give a one lead ECG that shows if I am in A fib or not using the app on my IPhone 6, and knowing give me peace of mind.  I can get an over read of the ECG by technical or medically professionals if necessary. My physician recommended the App to me and I am glad he did.  I can send the ECG to him if I have an episode. I would recomment it.

was experiencing some chest fluttering, and decided, on my own, to purchase this to see if it would help determine anything.
it did !! So when I did have an appointment with my cardiologist, I mentioned I had this tool ( & the app) and he immediately said  "let me see!"
he was familiar with the product, and said it was great that I had it, and to continue using.
great purchase.
Easy to use.

I have been fortunate..no real problems since last year. However I'd like to see a design change. I had my alive core secured to my phone with heavy duty velcrose. Didn't want to use the sticky tape that came with it b/c I was worried about its strength and getting it off if I needed too. After maybe a year I looked down and my unit was gone. I got another one. I did not want to order the one with the iphone case because I like the case I have. I was thinking about other ideas to suggest: maybe a container that hold the device and clips on to my keyring? or could be hung on my purse or belt?  I'm afrasd to stick it on my phone now. I probably bumped my phone and it fell off. Not sure what happened. I have a clip on my phone which I attaches to my clothes and so I cannot put it on my phone directly. It barely fits as it is but the device fits accross the end of the phone. Just a thought. Thanks.

As of yet I haven't been able to use the device to give it an accurate rating.  It is not compatible with my phone. I intend on getting a new phone as mine is also older.  However, all the phones on the comparability list are old models and can only be purchased in a used condition.
I do not want to buy a used phone for any reason.  that would also defeat the purpose of buying a NEW phone.

I was having heart palpitations and was getting worried about my heart health. Testing regularly gives me peace of mind that I hopefully am not on deaths door. Meanwhile I have been making better life choices that support heart health. The technology in this ultra portable ECG is simply amazing. And you know that they care because it is priced affordably so that most people can afford it.

I take daily readings to detect any recurrence of afib since a successful ablation.  So far so good.  My cardiologist said that because of the daily monitoring he was ok if I deferred a semi-annual recheck.

One suggestion is that Alive Cor add a reading of sinus bradycardia.  My heartbeat occasionally drops below 50, which is normal for me, however, AliveCor reports that as unclassified.

I am extremely pleased with the quality of the KardiaMobile reports and the ease of generating and saving them. I suggest, however, that AliveCor improve the instructions, for some basic requirements were elusive. For example, it took too long for me to learn that it will not work unless I unplug my phone's charging cable, and it will not work unless I remove and turn off my hearing aids.

Use it a lot and 80%!get great recordings. Then for unknown reason it just stops recording. Let it sit an hour or so and its working again. Use a little gel or moisten slightly w alcohol.  Also being straight there are some dogs and cats it just won't fit on. In those care so far reasonable success with  using the paws.   Overall good but some drawbacks as above that I can't get around.

AliveCor  was recommended to me by my cardiologist as a way for me to self monitor my a fib issues.  The sensor and the app allows me to have a complete record of my a fib episodes.  Additionally, I can immediately text a PDF file of an irregular heartbeat record to my cardiologist for instant diagnosis.  I highly recommend alivecor for anyone wishing to keep tabs on their heart health.

Not clear to me what is going on. How do you decide whether there is an abnormality? Also, Don't know how I would send it to my cardiologist if I found one. Also, don't know how to adjust the smoothing algorithm to pick up finer detail.   I haven't had any significant irregularities in a good while now, but when/if I do, would like to have answers to these questions.   Thanks.  Michael.

I love the device. Two great reasons for liking it so much are the satisfaction of knowing that my heart is in a normal range; and the fact that I’ll have some actual information to show my doctor at the next follow up appointment.
I won’t have to rely on just the day of EKG, and my descriptions of how things have been going!
Very easy to operate and reliable in that regard. Thank you.

Unfortunately, makers should anticipate user phone upgrades and design interchangeable device. I stopped using mine (received complementary with UCSF's heart study) when upgrading to iPhone 6+ despite possibility of recording with the old case/recorder being in the new phone's proximity, as that approach did not deliver and signal was too weak and recordings would frequently interrupt.

I bought this as a gift for my mom.  Unfortunately when the unit arrived, it would not work.  As a last resort, I had my mom put a new battery in it and then it worked.  From that point on, the unit worked fine.  It is a nice device to give peace of mind for heart rhythm problems.  My only complaint is that it arrived with a dead battery but that gives a poor impression from the start.

The product works great and is an asset for folks that need a constant watch on their heart condition. But what is not clear when you purchase this item is you have to buy a subscription to the service or the darn thing doesn't work. And if you want anything more there is also an extra cost. For someone who just wants a reading say every 6 months it's expensive and would not recommend.

Two of my doctors have recommended the KardiaMobile so I thought I'd try it.  This is simple to use and has a great amount of information. The EKGs are stored in the app and can also be sent to my computer and to my doctors (PDF files). It takes up no space at all so I can carry it in my purse or luggage. I purchased the Carry Pod too which is necessary to keep it clean and undamaged.

The device arrived quickly and the app was easy to install on my phone. I have 2 valves in my heart that leak and they cause a heart murmur as well as tachycardia. This device is so easy to use and it is very accurate. So glad I made this purchase. It definitely gives me peace of mind to know I can monitor my heart condition at home and easily transfer the data to my cardiologist and primary care physician. Excellent product.

Handy little device to take a 30 second EKC whenever you feel there might be something (flutter, odd feeling in your chest, etc) you want to check out. It's default settings send you a lot of little notifications which can be annoying (like reminder to take an EKC, take your medication, etc.) but they are easily turned off in the settings. You do have to have your phone right next to it in order for the app to take a reading.

AliveCor has amazed me and the doctors at Texas Health ER at the accuracy of the read out. Each time the results are abnormal I have taken the print out to the ER. They run their EKG and the results are exactly the same as the AliveCor diagnosis. I have recommend this unit to several people that have been interested. Even a nurse that works with the home health care said it would be great for them to use with their patients.

Both my physicians and I like your Mobile ECG very well. What I don't like is the quality of your analyses. Most of the time you respond very quickly, especially over these past few months; but, the analyses are very abrupt and often in error, which have sometimes unnecessarily required me to seek medical attention or review. I would suggest that you either discontinue the "read" service or make steps to improve the quality.

Couldn't get it to work at all.  None of the troubleshooting tips worked, so maybe I got a lemon.  Battery cover broke the first time I tried to open it to replace the battery... not a good sign of quality.  For not much more money I got something else that has USB power, connects to my phone through bluetooth, and doesn't require a subscription service to save unlimited test results.  I do not recommend the product at all.

This single lead ECG is a more convenient recording, but doesn't offer as much diagnostic potential as it only looks at the heart from 1 angle. For those seeking a more detailed ECG get the KardiaMobile 6L instead.

Otherwise, it's a great little device, works every time and helps to assess your situation better.

It's accurate, and the battery lasts at least a year. I reccomend to anyone concerned with their heart health.

I like having the feeling of security with the AliveCor ECG with me all the time.  Sometimes I worry about the accuracy of it.  There have been times in the recent past when I have been completely still and silent and I get the reading that is is unable to read because I need to go to a more quite place. One time it was 11:00 at night when I was lying in bed! I hope it is accurate so that I have good protection from AFib.

I've had my Kardia for about 2 months and it doesn't work.  I've had trouble getting a signal since I got the device but eventually it worked.  Yesterday it stopped working completely.  I understand there are lemons with anything, but I've taken about 10 readings and now my device is dead.  Don't have any batteries handy but that's my next step.  Thinking I shouldn't have to go out and buy new batteries.

Very skeptical

I purchased my Kardia unit about a year ago at the request of my cardiologist in order to record the times I go into AF.  I get more "Unclassified" readings than I do normal or AF readings.  Sometimes I have to take 10+ readings before I get one that is recording anything other than "Unclassified".  I can't seem to find out how to get a better eading or even if that is possible.  Seems like I may have wasted my money :(

Even though I have a pacemaker/ ICD, Kardia Mobile has saved me several times so far. Letting me know if I was in Afib or Tachycardia. I was able to tell the 911 operator immediately what is going on for a fast response before it progressed. Gets rid of the guessing, I know what is happening and the action to take.   I'm going to upgrade to the six lead version to help my Doctors get a better picture of my cranky heart.

First off I want to say that I am a physician.  I am an internist and have been reading EKG's everyday on the job since 1988.  No doubt tens of thousands by now, and was excited about the device when I found out about it when I myself thought I had A fib.  I have had 2 different Alive Cor monitors.  The first one I bought produced a high quality tracing.  Unfortunately it quit working after only a couple of weeks.  I was sent a replacement monitor.  That one doesn't produce a tracing that is of sufficient quality to determine the rhythm.  I can see QRS complexes and I can tell if the rhythm is regular.  But P waves can almost never be seen (even when I know I am in sinus rhythm).  Very disappointing.  I was hoping to be able to recommend the device for my patients.  I hope the reliability of the device can be improved because if it could it could help a lot of people.

Gives me instant feedback when I want to know what y heart is doing.  Although it always says normal when I have arythmic heartbeats which is Not normal.  Its nice I can forward the results to my doctor but the process  to do so is not intuitive so there should be an easy key that creates the pdf of one or more starred readings and texts it automatically without having to reenter the doctors phone number every time.

I love my AliveCor Mobile ECG...but the 2nd one in 6 months or so  has stopped working, at a most inconvenient time. I am awaiting an ablation on January 21, and really need it now. I have uninstalled the app, and reinstalled, still nothing when I hold the device appropriately. Will call Monday and believe AliveCor will replace, but I truly don't understand why it just randomly quits, especially when I need it most!

It has allowed me, the patient to create a pdf of a lead one EKG rhythm strip for my cardiologist while I am sitting in a hotel isolated and under therapy for a severe heart beat disturbance.  This durn Wuhan virus crisis has prevented skin to skin therapy and so it has been a life saver over the internet.  The need for this device is very limited; but in its niche, it is extraordinarily useful..  May save my life.

I've used my AliveCor a lot, but there are times when I wonder if it can see what I.m trying to document. I also haven't been impressed with the redesign of the app. It seems to take up more space with stuff which takes away from the data, it gets constantly confused about portrait and landscape (it will record in landscape, but I have to put in details in portrait mode. Not as happy a consumer as I was a year ago.

Sensitive enough that it picks up a lot of things that require a doctor to read and assess. Great for giving you an idea of what may be happening. In my case, we were trying to learn when AF required medical attention and when it would be acceptable to seek no treatment. Great way to allow your cardiologist to see what is happening without an office visit every time, if you have a physician that will work with you.

No question there is value in ability to determine whether one is back in afib again. Some of us have no other awareness of the condition. This is a great product and much appreciated for the peace of mind that it provides.  My device on an iPhone 5s is a bit dated and the contacts could be designed a little better. Probably that has already been done for newer device models. Thanks again for a great product. Clyde

The unit works but it is not consistent....you sort of have to guess at which test is the most accurate....   and it gets interference often so have to retest multiple times sometimes.
Overall it was good value however...not bad..and it does give me an idea of whats going on with my heart rate.....

Example I do a test and its at 137bpm... I do the test ten minutes later and its at 84 bpm.

so...makes me wonder....

As a person recently diagnosed with atrial fibrillation that does not show through rapid heart beats, I've found the Kardia Mobile unit to be extremely valuable in letting me know exactly what my condition is at any moment.  It's an extremely easy unit to use, and I like the fact it keeps record of my condition when used.  I highly recommend it for anyone diagnosed with atrial fibrillation, as did my cardiologist.

I have been using this for some time and sending the ECG reports to my cardiologist when I am in A-fib.  He appreciates the information.  The only change I would make is adding the ability to write something about symptoms/activities in addition to using what is offered.   Also I have a case for my iPhone 5 but there isn't a case for the iPhone 6s.  I bought what looks like a stick on addition which ruins the look of the phone and provides no protection for the phone.  I recommended to customer service that selling rubberized cases would provide some cushioning for a phone but was told that the cases aren't advertised to protect the phone. No kidding! But isn't it a good idea? The idea is that you have the capability to check heart rate anytime you have your phone with you so doesn't it make sense to protect this expensive device and make it look good, or at least decent?

I used this after cardiac ablation to correct a severe afib condition earlier this year. Helped us to keep an accurate  record of what was going on in the months following the ablation. Worked great. Can't beat this set up, particularly at the price. Highly recommend it.  The ablation, also fixed the problem. While no walk in the park, it did the trick in my case (at least thus far). I highly recommend that also!

I bought the app after a long bout of palpitations. I wanted some way to do a self check to see if all was OK. I reviewed the app and results with  my cardiologist and he was impressed. Now, when I feel like I need a consult, I can email the results to him or to the folks used by AliveCor. Either way I get an answer.  AliveCor is a great little app for anyone with heart trouble. And it's great for peace of mind.

Hello, I was a very early adopter of the Alive cor device. I liked using it and patients really liked iit to. When I updgraded to iPhopne 6 obviously the cover did not fit. For a brief time it seemed to work via blue tooth, but that soon gave wave. I have been too busy to contact your firm to discuss my options. Whe it worked for me it was great.  I woudl appreciate it if someone got back to me re this. Thanks.

This appears to be an awesome little gadget and app. It is amazing that I can do this at my house instead of having to go in to the doctor and get a referral etc etc etc. That said, I have no known heart issues so I would not necessarily suggest that to someone who does. I just like to keep track of my vitals now and again to make sure I have no issues and am as healthy as I think I am. Kudoes to the inventor!!

I was having panic attacks which I thought was a heart problem. Had full tests done at my Cardiologist including wearing a very high tech new heart monitor/patch for a month. We were not able to capture my episodes during the monitoring because I didn’t have one during that time. Cardiologist gave me all clear and said my heart was fine. I wasn’t convinced. It just didn’t feel right. So I bought the Kardia Mobile device just to give myself peace of mind. I captured many “episodes” on my device that read as AFib. I sent the reports to the Kardia Mobile cardiologist who confirmed I was having AFib. I went back to my cardiologist who confirmed I have AFib and I am now being treated for it. Although I was having panic attacks I was also having Afib episodes and this device confirmed my suspensions which led me to proper care which I feel possibly saved me from a stroke or worse.

While I had hoped we would not need this device, it has been very helpful in monitoring a family member's heart condition. While the interface and device is easy to use, it is not Android friendly and it is very particular on what devices it connects to. This limits the types of phone we can have to ensure this device works. It would also be nice if it came with a carry case so that it does not get scratched and banged while being transported.

I purchased the KardiaMobile two weeks ago.  I have persistent AFib most of the time, with occasional periods when I am out of AFib, although I am unable to detect when in AFib. The technology of this device is incredible.  AliveCor could not say if it was compatible with my LG model G7 ThinQ phone because they had not tested the device with that specific phone.  Regardless, I purchased the device and it is compatible with my phone as well as with my wife's IPhone.  The device is easy to set up, and fast and easy to operate.  The results compare favorably with results from EKG in cardiologist office.  Most of my readings  are indicated to be Possible AFib, with occasional Unclassified readings.  Readings for my wife, who does not have any known heart issues, are indicated to be Normal.  I email the charts to my cardiologist on a weekly basis.

I purchased a unit within 10 days of its introduction into the market.  As soon as I installed it and ran my first ECG, I realized I was in atrial fibrillation.  I have since been treated medically and later surgically and have been in normal sinus rhythm ever since. I run a strip once each week just to document my results. I have recommended it to several friends and even my cardiologist now recommends it to patients. A wonderful invention.

I use the Alivecor device on my son's chest as opposed to using it on the hands. I bought it when he was 11 months old and have had it for two years. We've been able to send PDFs to our doctor and it has saved us a few trips to the ER, so it paid itself off quickly. Unfortunately it's not calibrated for children, so the alerts for Afib etc don't apply to my son, but it still gives accurate enough readings for whether or not he's having tachycardia (which I, as a person who is uneducated on reading EKGs, base my judgements only on heart rate). Our doctor is careful to remind me that the alerts are not accurate and I shouldn't put too much stock in what this says.  I'm proud to say I've only called the doctor in an unneeded panic once.   I like to use it as a log of events--I take notes on the EKGs when he's sick or looking pale. I recommend it!

The EKG gives a good waveform and has built in filters to remove noise, flip the signal if you have the device upside-down and detect atrial fibrillation. I like how you can turn the smoothing off and that you can email a PDF of the printout.  The ability to have a technician or a doctor interpret the data for a reasonable price is useful for users without formal medical training.  My main complaint is that customers cannot email a CSV file with the actual data from the EKG, as it would be a smaller file than an image and would allow customers to plot the data themselves if they wanted to.  I also wish the product came with a carrying case to protect it.  Another useful optional accessory would be wires with alligator clips to attach electrodes, which may make it easier to remain still while using the device and yield more-accurate information.

Mobile AliveCor did not work very effectively for me until about two weeks ago. More than 90% of my readings were put in que and never resolved. hat experience reduced my willingness to use the App.  It seems to be working better now.  Only 1 in 4 or 5 readings have not produced a reading.  The App is not too difficult to use, but requires that one take time to figure out - it is not widely intuitive.  For me, that's somewhat of a problem.

The system does work.  The phone app was easy to setup.  Wet finger tips starts the recording and it records for 30 secs.  You can save the recording and also send to your doctor if you want and print out s hard copy.  It only diagnoses three things, AFIB, tachycardia, bradycardia and also normal.  The finger tip pad is very sensitive.  The slightest movement will cause the recording to stop or give a few flaky waves.  If it stops you can start it over.
