I ended up returning this item.  The directions had you place the case on the back of your phone but I could not get it to stick correctly.  Plus my phone's microphone wasn't able to pick up the noise the device creates while on the back of the phone.  I would have to take the device and place it at the bottom of the phone.  The interface was good.  After a few times using the device it recognized my EKG and would notify me when my wife would use it that it didn't think I was the one using the device.  I also wasn't sure about having to pay a subscription on top of paying so much for the device.

After being diagnosed with both AFib and Flutter, I wanted to be able to monitor the state of my heart without having an office visit for their ECG. Had a flutter procedure which solved that problem and last year, pulmonary vein ablation which also was a success. I sent ecg graphs from my Alivecor from my iPhone 5 to my Doctor, before and after the procedure. He was very positive about having this info without taking office time. After several months of weakly to monthly readings, I am now off of Afib and warfarin and obviously pleased to be able to watch my progress in real time and at home!!

It was recommended to me by a friend with similar heart irregularities. I used it for a few days, logged my EKG’s, and all were normal, “I don’t need this!” Today, there was an irregularity, ‘Possible Atrial Fibrillation’, and THAT made me take notice. Coincidentally, I have a heart doctor appointment tomorrow that I’ve been waiting a month for, and will now find-out what it all means. My Kardia Mobile was worth the expense, I was NOT taking my condition seriously, and now my Kardia Mobile is part of my daily routine and will continue to use it as it has alerted me to a heart-health situation that would have been ignored had I NOT had it. I was foolish!
Thanks, Kardia Mobile, I needed that!

AliveCor is a great tool for my peace of mind.  It's very re-assuring to sit down for 30 seconds after exercise or whenever and take a quick ECG to verify that I'm not in AFib.  It's so pleasing to see normal sinus rhythm.  (Your cardiologist or PCP can show you what to look for in a 2 min lesson, and you can find on-line references to refresh yourself.)  And when I did have what looked like an episode of AFib, I was able to email a PDF of the ECG to my cardiologist so he could see what I was seeing, rather than waiting to go into the office and sit at the machine and probably not have an episode while they were looking at me.  It's a great tool that's helped me stay calm and manage my AFib.

I have been with the Health e Heart program since the very beginning.  It is so amazing to be able to be part of something that will shape health care in the future.  Patient centered care will be the standard and this device with be a major part of that.  I have shared it with my Primary Care physician. Want to get a new iPhone but have been delaying doing so because the AliveCor Mobile device would not fit the new phone.  One of the great things about it is that the program has improved dramatically.  Much more information is being collected daily.  Thanks for the opportunity to participate.

KardiaMobile is enabling me to collect the data for my cardiologist to assist in a proper diagnosis of my ongoing (7 years) incidents of afib and total heart flutters (spasms) whenever they arbitrarily pop up and disrupt whatever activity I might be doing. It’s been EXTREMELY frustrating trying to document my explications of my heart episodes so as to get guidance in solving my ongoing “electrical” problems…until now….I’ve been able to record EKG data and may soon be a candidate for the ablation procedure… we’ll see but at least I finally feel like I’m “fighting” back…,thank you KardiaMobile!

This is a fantastic device and when I show it to doctors, nurses, potential buyers, they are all amazed.  I use it whenever I suspect something isn't right.  I create a pdf file of it and email it to my cardiologist.  Sometimes I send it to my printer.  Recently, after recording 3 ecgs over a period of an evening, night and morning, I called my cardiologist, asked him to check the ones I had sent and after doing so, he sent me to the hospital for a cardio version.
You ought to pay me a commission on any that have been sold because of my telling others about it and showing them how it works.

I have only had this device a short time. The delivery was fast. It was recommended to me by my cardiologist. 
I used it a few times and sent my results to my doctor as soon as I got it to be sure it was working correctly. She received it as soon as I sent it. Since then, I had a few episodes of irregular heartbeat and some fluttering. I sent the results and she read them and assured me there was no indication of serious heart problems. I also like that I can keep the strip in PDF format for future reference.  I have had irregular heartbeat for many years. 
At least I know the device works.

I bought two AliveCor heart monitors from during my business trip in U.S , when back in China, I gave one of the devices to my mum, then the headache comes, she found no app to download from China AppStore, and after years I almost forget the password my U.S Account and can not help her by using my account at all ... , the tedious registration steps for new US account on behalf of my mum are so boring, so would you please launch the aliveCor app into China AppStore ? The English User Interface is not a problem at all, we're all well educated people, It's really a convenience for customers!

I was diagnosed with AFib and they performed a cardioversion to shock the heart back into a regular rhythm.    Having the KardiaMobile has been great to periodically check to ensure my heart has maintained with a regular rhythm and not gone back to AFib.    

When I had a question to my cardiologist about reducing my blood pressure meds, I mentioned I had this device … and he asked to see a few of the results.  Nice to know he finds the product that reliable.      

When I was having issues getting readings, I called support and they deemed my unit needed to be replaced and they sent a replacement immediately!!   Very impressed how quickly they send a new unit and stood behind their product.

My wife was in ICU with heart failure due to months of undetected AFib, the cartioligist recommended Kardia to home monitor her AFib. After being home for two days we hooked up Kardia to her iPhone in 2 minutes we sent the first reading to alivecore and within a few hours had the reply with the ekg letting us know she was back in AFib. We were able to get her back to the hospital and address the issue before the heart was redamaged. As she has no symptoms with AFib we rely on Kardia to monitor her rhythm and prevent heart damage. Note: after the initial reading by alivecore cartioligist, all other readings are immediate and e mailable to your own doctor.  We rely on it, we trust it. 
The Fullers

I have used the Kardia device for more than a year, and I am very satisfied with its performance.  I even bought one for another member of my family as a gift.  My only complaint with the system is the requirement to log onto the website each time before I can use it.  That becomes tedious after several tries and many failures.  I am 81 years old, and the tiny type on the phone is almost impossible to use without at least one typo when typing the password.  What is the reason for that requirement, if I only want to review it myself, and don't want to have the results reviewed by your team?

I’ve had intermittent heart issues since my 30’s. As I’ve gotten older they are happening more frequently and lasting longer. Saw a cardiologist who couldn’t see the issue after all the normal tests. He told me to buy a Kardia and showed me his. A few months later I had an episode that lasted 7 hours and got multiple EKG’s. I now have a diagnosis of AFib and have an ablation scheduled soon to fix it. Thanks Kardia. It never happened in the doc office (or the ER! It stopped right when they hooked me up) so this machine is a lifesaver. Really grateful I never had a stroke before buying this!

I am a nurse. I had the first generation on my iPhone 5 within days of its approval. The ability to assess an ECG at bedside has made a big difference in the number of people I have sent to the ER. The calming ability of showing someone they are not having a heart attack is greatly under reported. I have also helped identify electrolyte imbalances and heart block incidents bcz of its accuracy during events while waiting for equipment and labs. This new generation appears even more user friendly and is a must to update to as I update my phone after 2 1/2 years of use. It was ordered the same day as my preorder for the iPhone 6S and I could not imagine upgrading and not having this ability in hand.

I bought my Kardiamobile five years ago at the suggestion of my cardiologist when I developed atrial fibrillation. I have used it multiple times a day through these years of heart rhythm problems. It has worked for five years with a few battery changes. I’d love it! It has never malfunctioned! I have used it on friends, and one friend credits this device for getting him to a cardiologist and saving his life.I have not paid anything but the original price and do not feel pressured to spend any money while using it. It generates reports I can take to my doctor. I highly recommend this!!

My husband and I have been using this device and we like it. What I like about it is that you can use it with iPhone or Android phones. So we each downloaded the app on both phones. It's a relief when you see the results being normal. And the fact that this device is very accurate, makes me feel more confident.

It has been such a relief to me to be able to know when I am having PAC's as opposed to going back into AFIB.  I can't even say what peace of mind it's been able to give me, relieving the stress of wondering if I was going back into AFIBs (I used to go in and out of AFIB 20-30 times a day).  Now I know that the palpitations I feel are PAC's, it is a great relief.  The only recommendation I would have is that it would be nice if I could trace for longer than 30 seconds, and then stop, capture and record it when I find the 30 seconds I want examined.  I miss many events I could have captured had I been allowed to wait for it.  Instead I have to stop, delete, and then go again.  So that would be helpful.

I've had Paroxysmal AFib for years but it would never "act up" when I was near a medical facility so it could be recorded and verified.  My cardiologist is the one who recommended I purchase Kardia.  I'm fortunate that I can feel when my heart goes into AFib but I completely rely on my Kardia to let me know how fast and how erratic my heartbeat is so I can make the decision of whether or not to go to the ER for cardioversion.  I now have a second Kardia which I carry in my purse for those times when AFib starts and I'm away from home.  It may sound funny, but Kardia is my lifeline!

I like the portability, and the fast access when you need it. This is important to me since the problem I'm trying to get a handle on is intermittent and of short duration most of the time. When I get a recording that I need to share, I simply email it to myself, save on my computer, and send out as needed. It is easy, even for a technology challenged person. The images are clear and easy to read - if you know how to read ekgs - I am a rank amateur, but it is still helpful to me. I didn't purchase the version that alerts to more rhythms - I just send on to the doc if it isn't NSR.

I have used this app for 2-3 years, first with the monitor as part of an Iphone4s case and more recently I purchased the separate monitor for a new I phone 6s. Both work great. I like to travel in and out of the country and it's reassuring to be able to send off an email to my electrophysiologist with a recent recording. This is esp important when I'm in a remote location like the middle of China as I was recently. This app gives me piece of mind and has also been helpful to capture rhythms that have a way of converting to NSR the minute you get to the ER. I highly recommend it.

As I'm getting older this is a good cost-effective way to do a quick check on my heart. Though it is specifically designed to detect atrial fibrillation, it is also useful for determining overall heart condition in the comfort of your own home. Definitely not a substitute for medical EKGs.
It can be tricky to get it to read properly on the phone app, keeping the phone and the EKG Monitor very close together allows it to read properly,
For me, the subscription service at $10/month is not beneficial, but it could be worthwhile to someone that needs to track their heart condition.

It is hard to believe that something that costs so little can bring so much peace of mind.  I try to use mine morning and evening.  That way if I go into afib I have a definite time that I KNOW I wasn't in afib.  Having this information helps me to know if I have time to wait and see if I will convert back on my own, or if the situation has become more urgent and I need to go to the ER.  My doctor tells me they have done their own comparisons on the accuracy of the readings and find them to be very reliable. I would hate to have to give up the information this device gives me.
The ordering process was great, but the item purchased was not all it was advertised to be. There is a lot of interference with it working correctly. The EKG strip tracing can not be relied on!

This app is so incredibly helpful and easy because now instead of trying to explain in lay-terms what I am feeling or why something seems amiss, I can record it in 30 seconds and have it documented for my cardiologist. The old saying, a picture is worth a thousand words, has taken on a completely new and expanded meaning. God bless you all for your efforts and dedication. Monumental good is coming from your work and I suspect that over time, this little piece of scientific equipment, will lead to astounding results for all mankind. I am so very grateful for your efforts!

Love this product! I have the blood pressure machine that belongs to the same name as this product. And also stores it’s information with the same app. That is actually how I found this product. I decided to give it a try. I sometimes have a heartbeat that skips and wanted to keep an eye on it. This product is pretty easy to use. And has the option to have it sent over to your doctor. It can help categorize what your irregular heart beat is in terms of if it’s super serious where you need to get to the emergency room or if it’s undetermined. Both my husband and I use it.
This works very well. It gives both an EKG graph as well as beats per minute and a warning if BPM exceeds 100. It connects easily to a smart phone. I’m glad I made the purchase.

i am satisfied with the overall performance of the product.  it gives me an idea/picture of my heart rhythm most of the time.  sometimes it goes awry or is hard to interpret.  my pulse rate from the product at times will be WAY TOO HIGH mainly after doing cardio at the gym.  one time it read over 200 bpms, when it was around 100. at times it reads certain bpms during part of the 30 seconds and would vary differently (high and low) from the earlier readings without any change in pressure or movement. it can be sensitive to noise also.  also, since the upgrade earlier, it can be a pain to edit/delete the entries in the journal.  it's a pain to get the edit/delete option to appear.  you should go back to the older way.

Very easy to work with and doesn't require a bluetooth or wireless connnection to function. It uses the phone's microphone instead. Only real "downside" to this is it does need to be in close proximity to the phone for detection and NFC must be turned off. 

It does have a monthly for a free "diagnosis" of EKG results once every 90 days. But if you're just looking to monitor your own results and send them on to your doctor, it allows for a PDF to be saved to the phone and forwarded on. 

It even allows for guest usage so it doesn't add to your personal stored results.

Kardia mobile lasted 2 years and then had to be replaced.  Along the way it killed a couple batteries but gave no battery alert other than starting to function erratically.  It won't work unless I turn off my hearing aids.  In spite of these issues, I am pleased with the information it provides (most of the time).  Occasionally it can't record an ECG due to interference - I've never been able to identify the source of said interference.  My cardiologist was pleased with the reports - although the backup cardiologist at the VA was simply confused by the monthly report.
I guess it does what it is supposed to, but I don’t see how it is significantly enhanced over what I see on my Apple Watch. I’m not thoroughly impressed.
Works and looks exactly as described. Easy and fast to setup the app. Easy to check your rhythm. Absolutely worth the cost.
The backing to the adhesive on the phone clip will not come off. The removable strip will not separate from the adhesive.
There’s a learning curve involved but once you get it it’s easy and it’s goid to see if there’s a change in heart rhythm.

As an easy single-lead EKG machine, this device works reasonably well. If your only diagnosis is atrial fibrillation and you own an iPad or iPhone, then you really should have this. My only reservation is that the signal is just not clear and steady enough for several other diagnoses. There are many other electrical problems that can affect the heart, but this device is not much help with them. Still, it has its place. I use it for routine monitoring at least once a week, and I am very glad to have it. When used together with an inexpensive blood pressure cuff, it can give you peace of mind when you are doing well, and warnings to head to the ER when you are not. Just remember that it cannot possibly replace a full EKG.
Purchased, pick up was easy.  Product and app were easy to understand. Positioning of unit to my iPad works well

I bought this EKG monitor for my mom and the first one I received came empty with AAA batteries in it, it required me to go back to Bestbuy and swap it out. However, the second one I received worked great, it was small and easy to use. It has all the information for the doctor to decipher for you to make sure you are healthy. It's not something to rely on out, but it does give peace of mind for certain health conditions. I'm giving it a 4 stars mainly because sometimes it will spit out randomly out of range data, but the solution to that is to test multiple times.

Excellent price for a 1 lead EKG heart monitor. Easy to setup and use. Download the app, connect with bluetooth, and place both left and right hand middle nad index fingers on the lead and you can watch your heart rate cardiogram. There is a subscription portion to this which allows you to detech othr heart issues, but I think the basic would be good enough for most people. And if you're really worried about your heart, I would pay for the subscription. Allows you to PDF your EKG to send to your doctor which I think can be useful. You don't need an apple watch to do EKG for your heart, This one does it better and only $70 when I purchased it. 5 stars if it came with premium subecript free for at least a couple of months.
I am very pleased with kardia mobile, it records very well and and I have had no problems
Awesome working device you can carry with you wherever you go fits in your pocket.

I was excited when Alivecor was released after hearing about it for quite a while. I now have had it for over a year. I trust it meaning when I get a trace I feel that it is valid. The one continuing problem I have is that people have trouble holding it so that it works. I hold it and it initializes but then they hold it and nothing. back and forth as I coach them "Not so tight" or "Tighter" and clean or moisten the contacts. I do like the new feature which gives an opinion - Normal - if it is. Overall I am very satisfied with my Alivecor and would buy it again.
Very helpful when monitoring heart functioning.  Recommended by cardiologist.
Very small so very portable.  The app was easy to set up. Great device!
Easy to use device thx for the quick delivery Rob what else do you want

I am very pleased with the AliveCor reliability. There are a few software problems, mostly in notations about patients. It's not very intuitive, and sometimes I have to search for the right input areas. Filing is definately substandard, it would be grand to be able to search under last or first names, or an alias. I would greatly appreciate a more stable baseline. The ECG doesn't appear to become "quiet" for too long, and any muscle movement aggravates the baselilne, causing adventitial "events." However it is greatly improved from when it was first introduced.

I am an emergency medicine and critical care medicine physician. This device can save lives. I responded to a code blue on the hospital floor. The patient was not hooked up to a monitor. I turned on my AliveCor and saw that the patient was in VTach and shocked the patient as soon as defibrillation was available. Patient survived!
It is also a piece of mind. When a teenager fainted in a hot venue, I knew it was a simple feint from standing in the heat, but AliveCor was able to give the parent piece of mind that her daughters heart was fine!!
I love this product!
Very handy and portable unit to have to give you piece of mind.

I was a long time undiagnosed A-Fib sufferer, who was finally correctly diagnosed just over a year ago. A friend, who also happens to be an Electro Cardiologist, suggested your product just to monitor my condition. He thought I might be surprised with what I found with a closer daily/hourly monitoring... After 2 months AliveCor monitoring the results indicated I might want to consider options other than just treating my condition with pharmaceuticals. This product was an integral part of the decision making process to opt in for a successful Catheter Ablation.
Easy to set up. Good to have a visual of EKG and to know it can be shared. Gives a sense of security.

This little device is amazing! It monitors your heart and see your heart beat on the Kardia app! It also gives you your pulse rate and will let you know if your heart is beating too fast, or if there is an irregularity. Super easy to use. Just put two fingers from each hand on the little device and press start. Only takes 30 seconds. You can set it up to send results straight to your doctor, too!

I am 57, an age that I take seriously the condition of my heart. This addition to my self-health check-ups became very important. I love the quality and fast certified diagnosis. A must have along with the Blood Pressure check. The App is very simple, yet professionally done.

I have both the KardiaMobile (Single-Lead) and KardiaMobile 6L (6-Lead).  I keep the 6L at home and the KardiaMobile in my desk at work.  Both devices give me the same nature of results; I can't tell whether the 6L is more accurate or more sensitive, they both seem to detect the same kinds of irrythmias.  The KardiaMobile is easy to use at work, it just takes a few seconds, using two fingers, at your desk.  The KardiaMobile came with a felt carrying case with magnetic closure, included in the box.  At first I didn't quite understand how the KardiaMobile works, it doesn't use bluetooth it uses some sort of high frequency audio to communicate with your cellphone app.  So your cellphone has to be nearby and the microphone can't be hidden from the KardiaMobile, they have to be fairly close to each other and sort of pointing at each other, then they can communicate just fine. I find the real-time results so useful to understand what's going on.  This is so much more valuable than an annual check-up or a one-day Holter Test.

The Kardia Mobile Single is a fantastic idea.  Setup was easy and the instructions are easy.  Unfortunately using the pads has been extremely difficult to get a good reading.  I've tried several times over the week that I've had it and still did not get a stable graft.  My first try told me to move because of interference.  I wasn't anywhere near any other electronics or transformers.  My next try in the same location worked, but the graft was all over the place.  Tried all the suggestions given by the company online and have yet to get a clean graft.  The quality of the device is good, but you have to pay extra if you want a carrying case.

As a former AFib sufferer, this device has proven to be an invaluable tool for monitoring and detecting both normal and irregular heart rhythms.  The associated Kardia iPhone app records measurement results locally which enables the information to be conveniently presented to your cardiologist or GP during routine visits.  An optional subscription facilitates storing of the EKG measurements in the cloud.  The only criticism, in terms of usage, is that a firm/heavy pressure must be applied and maintained to the electrodes during the 60 second measurement period.  Placing the device on a table or firm surface is mandatory to avoid miss-reads.
Gf has issues with the electrodes that her cardologist uses so he recomended this device works very well she is able to message her results straight to her doc would recomend. Size of a cracker.
They tell you the battery can be replaced but that is not true for certain models. Better tech support needed. Not all models have replaceable batteries

Product is a great idea, but the electrode piece is too small to comfortably just sit and place your fingers on, and too easily moved to interfere with getting a good ekg. I have a prosthetic aortic valve and I’ve yet to get a good ekg from it since purchase. All I get is that my readings have too much electrical interference no matter where I sit to do
This. The idea was to purchase this device and use it to create EKGs and send them to my cardiologist on a weekly basis, but with no readable ekgs that all went out the window. My advice is stay away from this device until they improve the size and stability of the electrode piece of the equipment.

The AliveCor is truly excellent.  

Was introduced to it by my cardiac surgeon after my first cardiac ablation to monitor myself.  Six months after being weaned off the Amiodarone, the unit picked up another AFIB.  Of course it was a weekend, and only the on call cardiologist was available, but here was the magic...  He said...

"Ok...  relax your arms to get a clean strip and TEXT it to me..."   Don't come to the office, don't go to the ER, just relax your arms, get and clean reading and TEXT it to me....  Now that is the future of medicine.

I've taken over a thousand readings with my AliveCor over the past 4 years.  Best investment I ever made.

I bought Alive Cor and also got an iPhone on my doctor's recommendation. He had seen it at a conference and wanted to see how it worked.. I found it awkward to use because of having to attach it to my iPhone with adhesive. The adhesive was poor and made my phone sticky. I had thought I could use Alive Cor to send ECG tracings to my heart doctor for his evaluation,  but instead kept getting dunned to send my ECG Tracings to someone, not my doctor, to be evaluated for a stiff price, not covered by insurance. This product taught me an expensive lesson: Don't let your tech-happy Doctor talk you into something expensive  because HE wants to try it out!

I purchased the AliveCor app with the electrodes after I had a round of A-Fib.  I am a paramedic and have lots of experience in reading EKGs.  The AliveCor app generally does a pretty good job.  It is obvious that the initial reading has lots of artifact, but there are algorithms that seem to eliminate most, but not nearly all, of that artifact.  Generally, what's left is a fairly decent version of lead 1, but there are still lots of movement anomalies, regardless of how still I am during the reading.  It is more than adequate for finding basic arrythmias, however.   I would purchase it again, but hope that they continue to work on the algorithms.

I got my monitor several years ago, using it with an iPhone4s and a now outdated operating system. My phone won't support the current OS. The Alivecor plastic case started falling apart a couple of years ago; it's been glued and taped together with electrical tape many times. The unit still works! The Kardia upgrade is not fully compatible; some of the Kardia features do not appear on this older phone, but many do. It records reliably. There are some abberations on some recordings which appear to be frequency interference related, but once you figure out what they are, it is acceptable. I like the unit. A thumbs up (except for the case).

Purchased and started using early January 2015. Using 3rd gen unit on HTC One M8 and two Kindles. All three work well but it takes practice to get good conductivity. I worked 40 years as a printer and washed hands many times a day. My fingers are dry and thick, rough skinned. Finally found using a little salty water on my fingers and letting it dry enhanced my conduction on the pads. Tried moisturizers and other lotions but suspect residue actually blocked conduction.I now simply lightly blow on my fingers (like fogging a mirror) and that adds enough moisture to get good reading. The price of the unit is far better than anything else on the market.

I have a suggestion for a Christmas Gift for someone you love and care about.
I purchased this for myself a month or so ago.
Yesterday, I went to see my cardiologist. The good news is my carotid artery went from 73% blockage to 79.5% CLEAR. The Doctor and the technician both were shocked by the changes in the arteries.
Then I showed both of them my KardiaMobile.  I was in Atrial Fibrillation a number of times in late November. Which is the leading cause of Strokes.
My EKG History with the KardiaMobile records has now been downloaded to my Cleveland Clinic My Chart.
Yes, I am on a blood thinner now but I am thankful that we caught this in time.

I was diagnosed with Bradycardia and was unsure whether I might need a Pacemaker. Using AliveCor I've been tracking possible symptoms, Bradycardia and PVCs for about 9 months now. I find it to be a very reassuring resource and like that it saves my ECGs so I can share them with my Cardiologist. The one drawback is that it really cannot get a functional ECG in noisy environments. I cycle along some rather busy roads and occasionally would really like to check for PVCs. Unfortunately road noise prevents me from being able to do so. Beyond quiet interior spaces I find that it can be challenging to get a good ECG. Very happy to have this device, though!

I think the only real time monitor is a chest strap which could be combined with the Alive Cor and a smart phone.  The problem with the Alive Cor is one has to be still to take the EKG, thus stopping exercise and not getting a reading that reflects the heart working during exercise.  Recently, while using a chest strap on my stationary bike, I caught the very brief racing heartbeat I occasionally feel.  I was cruising along at 120 BPM and suddenly felt my heart racing for a few seconds.  The strap picked up 159 BPM.  I have never been able to capture that with Alive Cor because the racing stops before I can get Alive Cor to read it.

I like this product and I got it at a better price than the manufacturer's own website was selling it at the time.  However, what I didn't know was that you really only get one function with the product as it stands, and you then get offered a subscription to be able to get more data out the device.  That was a bit disappointing - especially since you know the device is collecting your health data but not telling you the results unless you sign up for a subscription.  Five stars for the product. Five stars for the ease of use.  Zippo for the lack of transparency.  As for the "recommend" I said "yes" but I was really looking for a "yes, but...." option.

Happy with the Kardia since mid 2019, after it became clear I had afib. It should be a staple part of the first aid kit. I can hardly explain how useful it is. The Kardia makes me less anxious, as I can be in permanent afib and I want to make sure I am not calling the hospital for nothing. Sometimes the pill in the pocket works and after testing with the Kardia I could let the cardiologist know that my heart had its rhythm back. This week I had to have a cardioversion and using the Kardia for accuracy I can let you know that the values were exactly what the monitor showed!. The battery lasts a long time too. 1 changed recently and I make a lot of EKG’s.

I can say that kardia saved my life. My cardiologist recommended it, because I was having palpitations in my heart that could not be explained, all the tests were performed did not show any problems, but I was not having the palpitations at the test time. When I purchased kardia, I was able to test myself at the very moment of the palpitations, and guess what, I have a heart condition, now I can take better care of myself, and the doctor prescribed a medication that will help me live longer. Without kardia I would have not been able to know and the condition could have killed me. Thank you alive for kardia! It is a great product.

I am really happy with this KardiaMobile. I had an implanted heart monitor for 13 months and did not feel comfortable keeping it in for another 3 years as recommended after my heart ablation surgery which so far has been successful-I have not had any worrisome episodes for afib and since this loop recorder (Heart Implant) monitor migrated more to my breast area-I did not want to keep it in since I had abnormal mammograms in the past. So far I have been checking my own heart with this less invasive device which is easy to use. I check 2x a day and feel so relieved that I have had no more episodes of afib or other related rhythms.

If you have a heart arrhythmia DO NOT BUY this product. It is very hard to get a clear reading from it if you sit calm. It's almost impossible to use it when you feel anxious because you'd just had palpitations or Afib. I would say that 3 out of 10 results taken when I was calm look correct. The rest have results are all over the shop (like, really, impossibly distorted). Even when you catch anything you have absolutely no idea if that was your heart or another problem with the machine.
Not to mention that you will become obsessed with checking your heart EVEN knowing that the results are unreliable.
I'm very unhappy about wasting my money for that product.

My husband has a genetic heart condition that sometimes causes bad beats and afib. To borrow an analogy, this device rectifies the "sorry, ma'am, we can't duplicate your problem" you hear at the mechanic sometimes about your car. You feel something, you grab the AliveCor and record it. Simple as that. He has had extensive treatment at the #1 cardiac center in America, and the medical professionals there were uniformly impressed with the strips the device produces. Well worth the money. We don't leave it attached to the phone, just keep it in its own bag and hold it in the close proximity of the phone when recordings are needed.

When used with emailing the pdf from a patient "event" to his Physician or Cardiologist, the App is a superb way of having continuous access to cardiac rhythm events occurring very infrequently. I am asking many of my patients to look at the website, phone application and electrodes embedded in the phone protective case, and it is giving me clinically important information that I was unable to determine previously with 4 weeks of monitoring. Obviously, the events must be long enough for the patient to record, and the patient must be awake and conscious to record them; but in the vast majority of events this is a wonderful addition to heart rhythm management.

Simple to use and provides an adequate 30 second single lead EKG.
I found at times that I have some trouble getting good contact with the sensors or a good signal to my phone. Repositioning away from the computer desk with a little moisture and pressure helps. I have always managed to get a readable EKG. I purchased this on the advice of a cardiologist to monitor PVCs which I have occasionally. I wish there was an option to capture longer than 30 seconds. You can always run another 30 second strip. So far I have not captured any PVCs. All EKGs I have taken so far interpret as normal which the device does for you itself. I guess I should be thankful for that!

I purchased this unit 2 years ago.  I purchased Kardiacare a couple months later so I would have access to the 4 cardiologist reviews.  I used the 4 reviews the first year.  No problem.  I renewed my membership  but the 4 credits did not show.  I contacted Kardia and thru gave me the 4 credits.  I used 2 of the credits.  When I attempted to use the 3rd credit the system said I had used all 4 credits.  I contacted Kardia and provided the dates I had used 2 credits and requested they reinstate the last 2 credits.  That was a month ago and nothing has been resolved.  I have requested a refund for the last 5 months of my subscription.  We will see if they respond.

I was told to purchase this device, then the PA in the Practice is “was not necessary for the Cardiologist to see any more of the reports, since it only proved I was in AFib and needed to stay on blood thinners (apparently, no matter the side effects.) So, my question is, what good is a device if it does not lead to further diagnostics and treatments? As a woman, I feel I have been stonewalled, and not just by that Cardiology group. The only want to treat the symptoms and “watch” the condition, while resorting to drugs to mollify the patient (or worse, to shut them up.) At this point, I am disgusted with the whole works, and ready to go back to my homeopathics.

I have only been a Kardia customer for only 1 week - I must admit that I am highly impressed by the power of this tiny device. I been recently diagnosed with COPD - and now find that I must change many things in my life. This situation has caused me a great deal of stress - not to mention the Anxiety Disorder that I already had - which only exacerbates the COPD. But my Kardia device allows me to rest so much better at night and all through the day - because NOW I am empowered to know 'the status of my cardiac health' immediately - giving me and my Cardiologist the much needed information to make quick and informed medical decisions to remedy my COPD challenges.

I have been using the KardiaMobile Personal EKG Monitor since mid-2020 after my Cardiologist recommended it. He keeps one on the back of his phone and his ARPN has a smartwatch which is built on the same analysis platform. It is not a substitute for an office EKG, but it is easy, fast and accurate way to detect irregularities in your heart rhythm. 

Most people will be satisfied with the free KardiaCare account. It will also allow for guest readings.

One caveat: Look at the list of supported devices. It does not work with my Moto G Stylus, so I use it with my Samsung tablet and an older Moto G phone. 

Highly recommended!

This product is a great way to capture an on the spot EKG when you are having symptoms and your doctor office is closed. I wish this was around when my sister was going through A/F. Her symptoms only happened away from any instant recordings. It took over a year and a half before she was lucky enough to be right in the doctors office for them to catch it on their EKG machine. Their was nothing they could do for her until they saw it. Thank you for having this easy to use product. Now when I’m having a problem I can not only record it, I can send it to my Doctor so he can see it. If nothing else it gives you piece of mind.

This device is a lifesaver! 8 days after purchasing it, I was feeling 
awful and suspected I may have gone into AFib like I did once before.  KardiaMobile confirmed it and told me that my heart rate was 204, so I went to the ER and got admitted. It is highly accurate and agreed perfectly with my heart monitor in the hospital. The one negative is it uses some weird ultrasonic method of communicating with your cell phone and it not compatible with my Moto G Stylus cellphone. I wish it used bluetooth like most other devices. It works with my work iPhone and my wife's Google Pixel cellphone, but it's inconvenient.
It really delivers peace of mind for me and my family.

I purchased my AliveCor almost a year ago to try to catch an ECG of a suspected paroxysmal SVT. While the app was fun to use, I ultimately stopped carrying my device due to the annoyance of the high pitch sounds it emits. I'm about 29 years old, and most of my friends and colleagues (myself included) could hear the squeal. When I set my phone on my desk. From my pocket. From my car mount. It was awful. A simple on/off switch would have gone a long way. I don't mind the sound when I'm actively capturing a reading, but I'll have to wait 5-10 years before the device stops annoying the hell out of me when I'm not using it.

I purchased the KardiaMobile a couple of years ago and it works great, with my old phone at least. They have stopped supporting the Moto G line. I understand this is considered a medical device and its functionality must be verified. However, AliveCore needs to either step up its certification program or give us a warning screen to click through. 

AliveCore, why don't you have an annoying warning come up every time you use this with an unsupported device? "I understand I am using an unsupported device. I could get misleading results that could be life-threatening" Something like that. 

Great device, poor support.

I purchased my Kardia Mobile just after Christmas after discussing it with my cardiologist. He did not recommend it because the average person would not likely know how to accurately read an EKG. In my case I am married to an RN retired after 40 years. Believe me, if I was left to my knowledge, it would be pretty useless in my hands alone. Medical professionals have years of training in reading EKG and there are a lot of subtleties in an EKG that my wife has a difficult time explaining to me. I'm not a dummy, I was an Architectural Designer for over 38 years. This may not be beneficial to the average lay person. Purchase with caution based on your medical knowledge.

Hi,  I love being able to record my own ECGs.  It gives me peace of mind when I feel little cardiac "hiccups".  The strength of my heartbeat varies, so I would like to capture the avg and strongest heartbeat during a recording. I have HCM, so my strong heartbeat does concern me.  I'm not crazy about the results I've gotten when I've sent my ECGs to you to review.  Both times I had unusual events captured, and your online cardiologist service reported normal sinus rhythm.  It would have reassured me if your cardiologist would have said normal sinus rhythm with environmental noise captured, and include a suggestion to put my phone in airplane mode while using Alivecor.

Since I had had an ablation in 2011,  I did not have to do all the fancy monitors to try to "catch" an episode of my paroxysmal AFib to qualify for a second ablation.   With AliveCor, I was able to document my episodes and email them to my cardiologist, to qualify for a second ablation in 2015.  This saved so much time, inconvenience, expense, and anxiety.  I also really appreciate having it with me, at home and our travels beyond our state and country, to verify what I feel.  I am amazed at how well it works and how easy it is for me to use when I am not a techno savy person.   Thank you to whomever developed this.

I always say that the worst thing you can do with an ECG is hold it by the electrodes. That said, if you don't have shaky hands, are looking for gross rhythm issues (AF, runs of VTach) then it's pretty useful, assuming the rhythms are persistent.   I don't trust the filtering for ST segment or QT interval analysis (and anyway you need several leads for that). The signal is just too smooth.  I find it annoying that the device has to be so close to my phone. I like to use it 'off-phone' and the range is very limited.  Being able to move it around the torso would be useful so i could explore several leads sequentially.

As a health IT professional, seeing more consumer products that promote preventative health and digital health to better people’s health makes me really happy. Although this doesn’t provide a comprehensive EKG, but it sure gives any user a basic baseline and if there’s a fluctuation, then it can detect it and be enough of a reason to seek immediate  medical help (i.e., urgent care, emergency department).

Especially for those without a series 4 Apple Watch (as it features an EKG also), this is a much cost effective alternative. The only downside is having to pay for the premium membership, which is a bit too pricey.

At first, I was not sure how well it would work. After playing with a little. It's great. Both Wife and I have illregular heart beats. I have an heart implant that records 24/7. But I'm not able to see the rhythm when it happens. Very easy to use and can sent a strip to the  Dr.. Can carry with you anywhere and works with your phone or tablet. The app has other ways to help track your help. This can be a life saver. I'm a Retired Paramedic and know how to read the rhythms. You don't need to know how to read them. It is able to pick up on some important rhythms. If you have heart issues, I say this is a great buy.

I wanted to use this to get a EKG for A Dr. Appointment. But they wouldn't except it one because they said that it's nothing like something u would get from a DR. OFFICE EKG 2. It only on lead so they don't think it could be that accurate 3. They make another with 6 leads so I bought this for nothing because I wanted to see what that one did! Ugh so frustrating  but I hoping customer service sees this post an wants to make Me a happy customer and let me trade this one for the six the six lead. Also coming out with other product that will connect more lead for the most accurate readings and diagnose heart attacks

Works beautifully and simply with my phone-very intuitive. Getting copies of ekgs to professionals is not so user friendly. My cardiologist recommended your product but unfortunately getting him copies is anything but straightforward-he has no work email so a couple of additional goofy steps are needed to get him involved.  Nothing in your information/instructions prepared me for navigating with that missing piece. Also  the instructions for your monthly plan are lacking/confusing  After almost 2 weeks using your product, I’m still not sure what to do, what options are available or if it’s worth the monthly fee.

Why is it so hard to save a PDF?  The core purpose of this product is to get the information into the hands of a healthcare professional but you have to go through flaming hoops to do that.  The very first / top option after recording an EKG should be saving a PDF directly to the download folder.  Period. Rather you have scroll  down for that option, then select "Download PDF" which doesn't actually download a freakin' PDF, then you need to open the report in Acrobat, go to the ellipses, scroll down and select "Save a copy", then select "On this device" - what the heck?  Who developed this use case?  This is absurd.  Download a PDF should do just that in one click.  Period.

Your device and application are superb. Having congenital heart defects has meant that regular monitoring has been a necessary and inconvenient burden for much of my life, but now with AliveCor ECG I have the freedom to go anywhere in the world (or off it!) and at anytime take an ECG should I feel the need. I proved this point recently with a 15 day trekking/climbing expedition in the southern Andes. My team members were impressed with the small size and the ease of operation. The fact I could use it on either my smartphone or tablet was an additional bonus. Thank you for this (potentially) life saving device.

I was introduced to the AliveCor device by my ElectroPhysiologist during a routine office visit, as he had just gotten one to test.  When they came available to the public, I had to get one.  While my afib isn't severe or frequent, I use my device regularly when feeling the little flutter-flutters flapping around in my chest.  Easy to use, and I feel confident in it. You have to accept the fact the there will be some funny-looking artifact at the beginning of the tracing, but once it gets going it is a breeze to use.  I've taken it into other doctors' offices to show it off, and nurses in particular love it.

I suffer from occasional Afib that has been fairly well controlled with Metoprolol for the last couple of years. But the Afib incidents have begun to increase over time and I was beginning to worry about them. My cardiologist suggested Kardia Mobile and it seems to be working very well. I have a new Samsung Galaxy 21+ and it is not yet listed as a compatible device with Kardia Mobile since they have not had time to test it out yet. However the Kardia Mobile device seems work just fine with it after I downloaded the Android app. Kardia Mobile is quick and easy to use and seems accurate. When you are not quite feeling right, it is comforting to find out if you are in Afib or not.

My Cordialogist suggested I buy it, since I have a high risk of going into Afib. I bought my 6L Kardia Mobile few days ago. I did not feel well and decided to use it for the first time today. It was simple and easy. I emailed my EKG to my Cordialogist and she told me I was in Afib. She treated me with medications and I have converted. Kardia Modile has saved my life. 
I STRONGLY RECCOMENDED KARDIA MOBILE TO ANYONE WHO IS IN A RISK OF HAVING HEART PROBLEMS. IT WILL SAVE YOUR LIFE. KARDIA MOBILE MADE IT POSSIBLE FOR ME TO GET EVALUATED BY A DICTOR WITHOUT HAVING TO GO TO DR’S OFFICE. DON’T WAIT. BUY IT TODAY

I'm impressed by the performance of the Mobile ECG. I use it frequently to check for paroxysmal afib. My episodes are infrequent and can be difficult to identify, since my medications tend to minimize easily felt rapid atrial flutter.The Mobile ECG has been very useful to verify those few occasions when afib "breakthroughs" occur. On several occasions where a definitive reading could not be obtained, I've sent the ECG to AliveCor for analysis, and the response was very rapid. My only complaint is that the small unit is somewhat sensitive to signal "artifacts", which can result in non- definitive readings.

Discovered after arrival that it required specific cell phones and I had to order a new phone that I did not want.  Then discovered that to set up the account required giving up my personal information to "the cloud" which is against my personal policies.  Who knows who has access to that "cloud" information.  Decided to send the equipment back.  Poor disclosure when order was placed about these issues - especially the requirement for specific phones.  Sending the equipment back.  Very disappointed in the disclosure requirements and the lack of ability to use it without giving up my privacy rights!!!!!!

I am a professor of exercise physiology. I have used the AliveCor almost daily for a year  to monitor my ECG immediately after exercise and when I wake in the morning. It provides stable measurements and is excellent for personal and classroom use. 

My only complaint is that it doesn't provide enough protection for the iPhone. I alternated between an Otterbox for phone protection and the AliveCor when I wanted to use the ECG. I got tired of doing that and went to the AliveCor exclusively. Within a week, I smashed the face of my phone. This is a terrific device, but I wish it protected my phone better.

I've had the Kardia 1-lead for 10 months.  No trouble setting up or synching with my i-phone.  Works perfectly.  For a year before I got the Kardia, all the office ecg's and numerous Holter Monitors were not able to "document" my recurring "palpitations".  One Kardia ecg graph during an episode was enough to establish a definitive diagnosis of atrial fibrillation!  Cardoguy took one look at the tracing I brought with me and said "Oh yeah, that's a-fib."  I joked with him about my "toy", and he said it's not a toy, it may have saved your life of saved you from a bad stroke!  Thank you Kardia!! (I have also tried a popular "wearable device", but the Kardia gives a MUCH cleaner graph!)
